nytimes_articles.headline: Abraham Kaplan, 75, Author and Teacher
nytimes_articles.abstract: Abraham Kaplan, an author and teacher of philosophy, died Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 75 and had lived in Haifa, Israel, since 1972.   He died of a heart attack while visiting a friend, said Allan Casebier, an associate professor at the University of Southern California.

nytimes_articles.headline: Foreigners in Germany (folo) : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding the report "Riots Galvanize Turks to Seek a Say in Germany" (June 2): .Turks are the largest group of foreigners in Germany, but only one-third of the non-German population, which amounts to about 5.7 million. There also are well-in

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, a report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about actions taken by the U.S. Home Corporation to raise capital referred incorrectly to the timing of the company's emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company left bankruptcy on Monday.

nytimes_articles.headline: B.C.C.I. JURY TOLD OF FUND SWITCHES
nytimes_articles.abstract: An important prosecution witness in the fraud and bribery trial of Robert A. Altman has told the jury of helping transfer hundreds of millions of dollars from the Bank of Credit and Commerce International to First American Bankshares, the Washington holding company that New York prosecutors say was controlled, with Mr. Altman's knowledge, by B.C.C.I.    But the witness, Imran Imam, a former B.C.C.I. officer, testified he never dealt directly with Mr. Altman on the transfers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Serb-Croat Plan to Split Up Bosnia Worries Mediators
nytimes_articles.abstract: The two international mediators for the Balkans expressed concern today over initial Serbian and Croatian proposals for dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina into three loosely federated ethnic states.   After talks here with leaders of the warring factions, Lord Owen, representing the European Community, said that he and the United Nations representative, Thorvald Stoltenberg, had been "rather disappointed" by the vagueness of the proposals President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia presented to them for partitioning the country.

nytimes_articles.headline: 92 Are Arrested for Failure to Pay Child Support
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nassau County officials today announced the arrests of 83 men and nine women for failure to pay court-ordered child support ranging between several hundred and tens of thousands of dollars.   The arrests came a day after a similar crackdown in New Jersey, where the authorities statewide arrested 324 people who were delinquent in paying more than $2 million in child support.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jays Find All Good Streaks Must Come to an End
nytimes_articles.abstract: Forget Jimmy Key and his return to Toronto for now. He becomes part of the story later, but he was just an extra by the time Steve Howe and John Olerud faced each other in the bottom of the eighth inning. It was the at-bat to decide the game. Howe and Olerud were the co-stars.   The Blue Jays trailed, 4-3, they had runners on first and third with one out and their .400 hitter batting. Olerud was hitless in his first three at-bats against Key and was desperately trying to maintain his 26-game hitting streak. Howe had been summoned to replace Bobby Munoz. The stage and all its players were in place at the Skydome.

nytimes_articles.headline: Credit-Card Tickets Got Better Treatment
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Last Thursday, when I went to see "Jurassic Park" at the Ziegfeld, a Cineplex Odeon-owned theater, I found a new policy toward moviegoers. I bought my tickets for the midnight show (tickets for the 9:30 show had sold out to those who paid by credit card over the phone earlier in the day). I discovered there were two lines for ticket holders: one for the privileged credit-card ticket holders, and another for the lowly cash ticket holders. By the time the ticket holders were let in, both lines were roughly the same length.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Panel Acts on Base Closings   In the first set of votes that will cause pain to many communities, a Government panel decided to close or shrink two Army bases but also spared two, one of them in New Jersey. Page A20. Iraqis Move Toward Iran    Iraq moved troops toward Iran and put air defenses on alert in its largest mobilization since the gulf war, American officials said. Page A3. Nigeria Voids Its Elections    The Nigerian military Government annulled the presidential elections held 11 days ago and abandoned its promise to hand power back to elected civilians soon. Page A8. Pratt & Whitney Pact Voted    Union employees at Pratt & Whitney plants in Connecticut approved a package of contract concessions aimed at saving 2,300 jobs. Page B1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alton Journal; Savage 'Horse Ripper' Panics English Countryside
nytimes_articles.abstract: This is lush country. Gently rolling hills and valleys are bathed in the blossoms of foxglove and honeysuckle and Jacob's ladder, and the green of the fields is so bright it shimmers over everything -- the sheep, the winding wooden fences, the stone farmhouses and red-brick cottages.   But something is wrong in Hampshire. Over the last three years, more than 30 horses have been savagely attacked. The attacks, which actually date back more than 10 years but are now occurring more often and turning fatal, have happened in open fields and inside stables, in broad daylight and on moonlight nights.

nytimes_articles.headline: Some Tax Prescriptions for the Ailing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly all the Western industrialized countries have been mired in budget deficits since 1989; they are likely to remain so for years. Several governments have now decided that they must fight their way out with tax increases, but their fears of angering

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: BOXING  Coggi Defends W.B.A. Title  Juan Martin Coggi of Argentina successfully defended his World Boxing Association junior welterweight title by knocking out Hiroyuki Yoshino of Japan at 2 minutes 15 seconds of the fifth round yesterday in Tokyo. Coggi knocked Yoshino down twice in the round before a straight left ended the scheduled 12-round bout in Coggi's 37th knockout. The 31-year-old champion was making his second defense. Coggi now has 62 victories to go with 2 losses and 2 draws.(AP)   Moorer Preserves Rating: Michael Moorer, a Detroit heavyweight, preserved his No. 1 challenger rating with the World Boxing Association by scoring a third-round knockout over James Pritchard of Louisville, Ky., Tuesday night in Atlantic City. Referee Arthur Mercante halted the scheduled 10-round contest at 2:36 of the third when Pritchard, having already been floored twice in the round, was trapped in a corner and unable to defend himself. Moorer is now 33-0 with 30 knockouts.(AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Income Tax Is Answer
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Mirror, mirror on the wall,   What's the fairest tax of all?    The income tax.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture with the Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the Mets and Joe McIlvaine, the leading choice to be their next general manager, was published in error. It showed Jerry Hunsicker, the team's assistant vice president of baseball operations.

nytimes_articles.headline: FUND FOR BUSINESS IN RUSSIA TO BE CUT
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration said today that a $4 billion international fund it proposed to help Russian state enterprises convert to private businesses would have to be shrunk because Japan and the Western European allies are too squeezed for cash to join.   "We are doing some serious arm-twisting on the Japanese and Europeans to try to salvage as much as possible," a senior Administration official said. "People understand that the idea is not a bad idea, but they keep saying to us: Where are we going to come up with this dough?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Sheffield Pleads Not Guilty
nytimes_articles.abstract: Attorneys for GARY SHEFFIELD yesterday entered a not guilty plea on behalf of the San Diego third baseman on a misdemeanor assault charge. Sheffield was not present at the hearing; the Padres are in San Francisco playing the Giants. Sheffield was arrested June 16 in front of an International House of Pancakes restaurant near the Astrodome. He spent almost 13 hours in the city jail while his team was in Houston for a series against the Astros.

nytimes_articles.headline: S.& L. Woes Impinge on Privileged Haven
nytimes_articles.abstract: June's languor has settled on the rich green reaches of the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club. Only the occasional golfer studiously addresses a ball on the shimmering, lush fairways, and there are just a few horses sheltering from the heat over at the cool emerald-painted barns.   But the lassitude is deceptive, for the members of this haven for the moneyed are confronting a deeply unsettling matter. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency assigned to clean up the savings and loan mess, now owns the place, after a default by its previous owner, and will sell it at a public auction on July 14.  Maharajahs and Stars    Even more distressing for a group of members who want to buy the club is what they call a near-betrayal by the Government: They say they got a pledge from Resolution Trust that they would have an advantage over other buyers at the sale, but now they fear that the agency, in an effort to help the taxpayer by getting the best price, will sell to a buyer who will destroy the club's exclusive way of life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bradley Passes 76ers' Physical
nytimes_articles.abstract: SHAWN BRADLEY, after a momentary scare, passed a Philadelphia 76er physical this week.   On Monday, the 76ers welcomed the 21-year-old center to their headquarters, measured him to be 7 feet 5 3/4 inches and proceeded to X-ray his entire body. An initial echocardiogram found "a shadow" on the heart, according to Bradley's father, RENIER, and the team ordered more extensive tests.

nytimes_articles.headline: Foreigners in Germany : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a foreign student living in Germany, my impression of the country in recent weeks is one of confusion and disgust. .The government rejects double citizenship and has dragged its feet on easing current citizenship laws. Germany's foreigners are contr

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Bill on Educational Standards Advances
nytimes_articles.abstract: The House Education and Labor Committee today approved the Clinton Administration's education bill, which calls for voluntary national standards and would offer grants to state and local authorities to develop plans to meet them.   The bill was supported on a party-line vote, with all 28 Democrats in favor and all 15 Republicans opposed. The Republicans complained that the bill's standards would effectively become mandatory. One Republican, Representative Steve Gunderson of Wisconsin, said the bill would "nationalize education."

nytimes_articles.headline: 3 Arrested in Protest Of Mass at St. Paul's
nytimes_articles.abstract: A mass at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in midtown Manhattan was disrupted yesterday by protesters who said they opposed homosexuals' participation in the service, the police said.   At 5:15 P.M., a dozen protesters moved to the altar at the church, at West 59th Street and Columbus Avenue, and grabbed the microphone that the assistant pastor, the Rev. Steven Harris, was using to conduct the service, witnesses said. One man wrestled Father Harris into a headlock, the witnesses said, as several other protesters yelled slogans from the congregation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Music Notes; Thomas to Head San Francisco Symphony in '95
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Tilson Thomas has been listed as a contender for the directorships of several American orchestras in recent years. But although he is still youthful at 48 and has been famous since his 20's, when he was regarded as the young American conductor mostly likely to follow in Leonard Bernstein's footsteps, Mr. Thomas has never been tapped for any of the posts for which he was presumed to be a candidate. And although his prolific recording activities, television appearances and guest conducting have kept him in the public eye, he has not held an American directorship since 1979, when he ended an eight-year association with the Buffalo Philharmonic.    That changed on Tuesday, when the San Francisco Symphony announced Mr. Thomas's appointment as its music director, starting in September 1995. The orchestra had been searching for seven months to find a successor to Herbert Blomstedt, the Swedish conductor who will step down after the 1994-95 season. Mr. Blomstedt, who has done much to promote the orchestra's international reputation through tours and an extensive series of recordings, will become conductor laureate.

nytimes_articles.headline: SENATORS TAKE UP CLINTON'S BUDGET WITH ACID DEBATE
nytimes_articles.abstract: The grand debate over President Clinton's package of tax increases and spending cuts opened at last in the Senate today, and Democrats and Republicans, well aware that the outcome is predetermined, seized the occasion to paint the economic differences between them in the starkest political terms.   The two sides suspended the invective long enough for the Republicans' alternative to the Democratic plan to be rejected. The Republican proposal would have capped spending on Federal benefit programs, frozen most other Federal spending and kept taxes at current levels. Republicans cast it as a tax-free way to reduce the Federal deficit; Democrats called it a sham because it simply decreed a halt to the explosive growth in benefits spending, without specifying how to halt it. A Turncoat in Each Camp    The vote against the Republican plan was 55 to 43. One Democrat, Richard Shelby of Alabama, voted for it, and one Republican, James Jeffords of Vermont, joined the Democrats to vote against it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Robert Shrock, 88, Fossil Expert
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robert Rakes Shrock, a geology professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who discovered a number of species of fossils, died Tuesday at the Reservoir Nursing Home in Waltham, Mass. He was 88.   He died of cancer, his family said.   Professor Shrock, who lived in Lexington, Mass., spent 38 years at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, starting as an assistant professor in 1937. He was chairman of the department of geology and geophysics from 1949 to 1965. He reached emeritus status in 1970 but continued as a senior lecturer for five more years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Washington Talk; Some Old Hands Shape A New Research Group
nytimes_articles.abstract: In Washington, old bureaucrats never fade away. They just incorporate.   Some of the leading lights of George Bush's foreign policy team popped up on the Washington stage today, calling a news conference to try to recapture the spotlight they enjoyed when they were helping to break up the Soviet Union and putting together the coalition against Saddam Hussein.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: CAB CALLOWAY, the legendary singer and band leader, was to have led the bill for an unusual concert, "The Jazz Connection: The Jewish and African-American Relationship," at Avery Fisher Hall tonight. But Mr. Calloway, 85, was sidelined by a fall in his kitchen on June 5 and is in the hospital recuperating.   To say that someone could replace Mr. Calloway at the concert would be unthinkable, said GEORGE WEIN, producer of the JVC Jazz Festival, which is sponsoring the program. "There is no substitute for him," he said. "He is one in a lifetime. So instead, we will play a record of him singing 'Minnie the Moocher.' " The song, a Calloway classic, contains the famous "Hi-De-Ho" chorus.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Honors for Runner
nytimes_articles.abstract: Villanova middle distance runner NNENNA LYNCH added two more honors to her credentials yesterday. She was named the women's GTE academic all-America team member of the year in the university division. Lynch, who was a star runner at Hunter College High School in Manhattan, was the Big East conference scholar-athlete of the year and is a Rhodes scholar recipient. She is a sociology major with a 3.92 grade point average and a member of Villanova's National Collegiate Athletic Association cross-country champion team.(AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Diminished Capacity  New Group 432 West 42d Street Clinton Through July 1  By Tom Dulack; directed by Scott Elliott; design director, Zaniz; technical director, Kurt S. Nelson; sound by Tom Kochan; production stage manager, Michelle Malloy McIntyre. Presented by the New Group, Sam Schacht and Mr. Elliott, artistic directors. WITH: Hayley Barr, Chris Delaney, James DeMarse, Neal Jones, Mitchell McGuire and Isiah Whitlock.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fernandez's Statistics Change With the Scenery
nytimes_articles.abstract: Twelve days ago, Tony Fernandez escaped from baseball's version of hell, the place where a team cannot win two straight games, where a pitcher has lost 23 straight and where both the manager and general manager who started the season are now unemployed. No longer muddling along with the last-place Mets in Flushing, Fernandez returned to the defending World Series champion Blue Jays in Toronto in a trade for outfielder Darrin Jackson.   But the improvement in scenery has not improved his demeanor, at least not today. There was no smile emanating from Fernandez when he was asked about being back in the city where he began his major league career at shortstop 10 years ago. There were no wonderful stories from him about playing before a sellout crowd every night at the Skydome and no theories about why he is playing remarkably better for the Jays then he did for the Mets. There was mostly gruffness as a player reputed as aloof was exactly that.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigerian Military Rulers Annul Election
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Nigerian military Government today annulled the presidential elections held 11 days ago and abandoned its promise to hand power back to elected civilians anytime soon.   The announcement was made in a decree signed by the military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who said "these steps were taken to save our judiciary from being ridiculed and politicized locally and internationally."

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Gut Girls  Cucaracha Theater 500 Greenwich Street TriBeCa  Through Saturday By Sarah Daniels; directed by Maria Mileaf; set by Vincent Mountain; lighting by Jeremy Stein; costumes by Mary Larson; original music and sound by Eric Liljestrand; dialect coach, Howard Samuelsohn. Presented by Cucaracha Theater. WITH: Joseph Fuqua, Pamela Gray, Lauren Hamilton, Deirdre Harrison, Kate Malin, Mollie O'Mara, Elizabeth Woodruff and Damian Young.

nytimes_articles.headline: Geneticist Is Badly Hurt In Mail Bomb Explosion
nytimes_articles.abstract: A world-renowned geneticist from the University of California at San Francisco suffered grave injuries when a mail bomb exploded as he was opening the package in his kitchen, an event that has sent tremors of fear and bafflement through the ranks of scientists.   Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said they had no suspects or motives yet in the bombing. They said they were pursuing many leads, including an intact return address on the package that blew up.

nytimes_articles.headline: PANEL BACKS BILL TO PROTECT CLINICS
nytimes_articles.abstract: With significant bipartisan support, the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved legislation today to make it a Federal crime to blockade or damage abortion clinics or to threaten or harm abortion providers.   Three of the committee's seven Republicans joined the 10 Democrats on the panel in voting for the bill. The four Republicans who opposed it argued that it was unbalanced because it would not protect anti-abortion demonstrators from attacks that threatened their right to free speech.

nytimes_articles.headline: Riddick Bowe & Co. File Suit Against Lou Duva & Co.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Heavyweight champion Riddick Bowe will fight former heavyweight champion Evander Holyfield, at least in court.   Bowe, his manager Rock Newman and his promoter, Spencer Promotions Inc. filed a $25 million suit against Dan Duva and his company, Main Events, as well as manager Shelly Finkel and Holyfield. The 24-page complaint, filed yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan charged Duva and Main Events with breach of contract, interference with prospective economic advantage and breach of fiduciary duty.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fernandez Departs to Praise and Posse
nytimes_articles.abstract: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez sat through his last public hearing at the New York City Board of Education yesterday, listening impassively to the same raucous mix of praise and vilification that he encountered in scores of meetings during his tempestuous tenure.   Mr. Fernandez's face reddened only slightly as a lawyer who has been a vocal opponent faced him at the podium to criticize, one more time, a controversial AIDS curriculum and to conclude: "Chancellor Fernandez is leaving us a lot of disgusting legacies."

nytimes_articles.headline: Mandela and Buthelezi Unite to End Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: After their first meeting in more than two years, Nelson Mandela and Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, one-time liberation comrades who now preside over the deadliest political rivalry in South Africa, promised tonight to travel together through war-torn regions in a joint appeal for peace.   Meeting reporters after 10 hours together at a Lutheran conference center outside Johannesburg, the two men said they had not resolved their differences at the talks on a nonracial constitution, where Mr. Buthelezi's group, the Inkatha Freedom Party, is the most important holdout.

nytimes_articles.headline: To Turn the Tables : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The White House has taken to using threats of trade sanctions in an attempt to manipulate the internal policies of foreign countries. In this manner, it is trying to direct everything from Chinese action on human rights to Japanese monetary policy. This

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943:Roosevelt's Wrath : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON - [From our New York edition:] President Roosevelt, branding as "intolerable" the nation-wide coal strike staged June 22-23 by the United Mine Workers of America, indicated today that draft-age miners who strike "without just cau

nytimes_articles.headline: Lasting Israeli Peace Means Compromise
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A group calling itself Pro Israel, in a June 10 ad, assailed the Israeli Government's peace initiatives, attacked the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations and distorted the record of Americans for Peace Now.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; It's Put Up Or Shut Up In A.L. East
nytimes_articles.abstract: BECAUSE this is the American League, with its balanced schedule and knack for putting off what is important to almost midseason, the really good bouts on the fight card usually do not start until June.   Well, it's here, and the heavyweights of the American League East, at last, are having at it. The Tigers, the Blue Jays, the Yankees and the Orioles -- the Big Four to the rest of the division's Little Three -- are in a stretch where, more likely than not, one of the enemies they care most about will be staring at them from across the field.

nytimes_articles.headline: Green for a Greeting, Red for Rape
nytimes_articles.abstract: At first it seems almost funny, that the Navy has produced a one-page guide on sexual harassment that reads like a 6-year-old's reading primer. On second thought, it's no laughing matter. Maybe this equivalent of the 1992 Presidential campaign's "It's the economy, stupid" is precisely what a service so deeply steeped in sexism needs to reform its ways.   The guide, which has been sent to all commanding officers for posting on military bulletin boards, defines harassment in terms of traffic lights. "Sexual assault and rape" gets a red light. "Expressing concern or encouragement" gets a green. Behavior that falls somewhere between a casual hello and a determined grope gets a yellow. Many women would agree that "unwanted letters or poems" is properly yellow. But "sexually suggestive touching"? Surely that qualifies for red.

nytimes_articles.headline: Iraqi Forces Go on Alert at Iran Border
nytimes_articles.abstract: Iraq has moved some troops closer to the Iranian border and put its air defenses on high alert in its largest military mobilization since the Persian Gulf war, American officials said today.   Intelligence officials have said the flurry of activity appears to reflect Baghdad's fears of a new Iranian attack rather than plans for an offensive strike of its own. But the moves have raised concern within the Clinton Administration, where officials say they are uncertain of Iraq's intentions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption yesterday about the inflating of a hot air balloon misidentified the location in New Jersey. It was downtown Trenton, not Solberg Airport in Readington.

nytimes_articles.headline: Los Angeles Panel Backs Restaurant Smoking Ban
nytimes_articles.abstract: A day after the tobacco industry sued to void the Federal Government's findings on the dangers of secondhand smoke, the City Council here upped the ante in the cigarette wars today by voting to ban smoking in restaurants.   The legislation would make Los Angeles the nation's largest city to forbid smoking by restaurant diners. Its chances of approval by Mayor Tom Bradley are considered good, although a spokeswoman for the Mayor said today that he had made no final decision on whether to sign or veto it before retiring from office next week.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Finding the Beauty and the Otherness of Bugs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Broadsides From the Other Orders  A Book of Bugs  By Sue Hubbell  Illustrated by Dimitry Schidlovsky. 276 pages. Random House. $23.    As Sue Hubbell explains in her charming new book, "Broadsides From the Other Orders: A Book of Bugs," the otherness of insects is precisely what first attracted her to the world of bugs. As a child she was frightened by an adult's threat that dragonflies, called devil's darning needles, would sew up her mouth if they caught her, and by visions of rose chafers devouring the beauty of the world.

nytimes_articles.headline: House Retains Space Station In a Close Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: Putting space research and jobs ahead of cutting the budget deficit, the House today endorsed the troubled space station by a hairline margin, probably insuring at least one more year of construction.   The station is several years behind its original construction schedule and has run several billion dollars over its original budget, set by the Reagan Administration a decade ago. And with the cold war over and the deficit growing as an economic and political issue, the construction of a permanently staffed orbital laboratory has steadily lost Congressional support in the last three years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Newspaper-Studio Clash: Not Exactly a Boffo Finish
nytimes_articles.abstract: The clash of titans -- Columbia Studios and The Los Angeles Times -- fizzled today. Their dispute, which promised to be as exciting as "Jurassic Park," ended up more like "Last Action Hero," Columbia's disappointing big-budget adventure.   At issue was Columbia's demand last week that The Times bar a freelance writer, Jeffrey Wells, from covering the studio. Unless the newspaper relented, Columbia said, the studio would make the newspaper's reporters and editors personae non grata.

nytimes_articles.headline: Budget Debate: A Primer; Cutting Through Claims and Counterclaims As Senate Ponders Ways to Curb the Deficit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Those watching the budget debate in the Senate on television today must have been numbed by the claims and counterclaims.   There were the Democrats, with their four-color charts, arguing that their budget would turn around the nation's economy by slashing Government spending, taxing the rich and lowering the deficit by more than $500 billion over the next five years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Theater in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Merchant of Venice  Intar Theater 420 West 42d Street Clinton  Through Sunday By William Shakespeare; directed by Peter Royston; assistant director, Rebecca Shroyer; original music by William Catanzaro; lighting by Diana Arecco; costumes by Steven L. Birnbaum; set by Ron Meadows. Presented by the Royston Theater Company. WITH: James R. Michie, Gregory St. John, Catherine Walter, Warren Watson and Jeffrey Eugene Williams.

nytimes_articles.headline: Blazing a Power Trail in the Adirondacks; When Senator Ronald Stafford Says Not in My District, a Whole State Goes Without
nytimes_articles.abstract: Now and then, an issue arises that spotlights the way things really work in the New York State Legislature. There is, for instance, the current tale of how the fate of arguably the most important environmental legislation of the year has come to rest largely with one man: Senator Ronald B. Stafford, Republican from Plattsburgh.   At stake is the creation of an environmental trust fund, legislation that would set aside at least $100 million for the state to purchase and preserve undeveloped land, including in Adirondack Park and in Long Island's Pine Barrens and along barrier beaches.

nytimes_articles.headline: At Last, Shout of 'Eureka!' In Age-Old Math Mystery
nytimes_articles.abstract: More than 350 years ago, a French mathematician wrote a deceptively simple theorem in the margins of a book, adding that he had discovered a marvelous proof of it but lacked space to include it in the margin. He died without ever offering his proof, and mathematicians have been trying ever since to supply it.    Now, after thousands of claims of success that proved untrue, mathematicians say the daunting challenge, perhaps the most famous of unsolved mathematical problems, has at last been surmounted.

nytimes_articles.headline: German Opposition Party Chooses a New Leader
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hoping to end more than a decade in opposition, the Social Democratic Party has designated a new leader, but not yet a new strategy, to try to oust Chancellor Helmut Kohl in general elections next year.   Rudolf Scharping, the 45-year-old Governor of Mr. Kohl's home state of Rhineland-Palatinate, won more than 40 percent of the votes in a poll of Social Democratic Party members on June 13 to pick a new chairman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Empire Blue Cross Suspends Chief Financial Officer Without Pay
nytimes_articles.abstract: The board of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield suspended the company's chief financial officer without pay yesterday because of questions about his role in submitting misleading figures to state officials.   The board had previously put the official, Jerry Weissman, on a paid leave after finding that the figures were in error. Saying that he had not yet determined what Mr. Weissman's role was, Otto G. Obermaier, the former United States Attorney who was hired by the company last week to investigate the matter, said he nevertheless wanted Mr. Weissman off Empire's payroll because of the situation's "enormous uncertainty.".

nytimes_articles.headline: Prosecuting Welfare Fraud Ineffective, Judge Says
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sentencing a group of people who pleaded guilty to receiving welfare payments fraudulently, a Federal judge yesterday declared that criminal prosecutions of such people were ineffective in combating that type of fraud.   The judge, Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, held that more progress could be made if ethnic and community groups worked to dissuade the people they represented not to engage in such crime and if welfare agencies strengthened procedures to curb it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kuwait to Seek Arrest of Sheiks Over Lost Funds
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kuwait has asked Interpol to arrest two members of the royal family in connection with an investigation into the mismanagement of public funds.   The two are Sheik Fahd Al Mohammad Al Sabah, who was last known to be in Bermuda, and Sheik Khalid Al Nasser Al Sabah, who is living in London. Both are close relatives of the Emir of Kuwait and ranking members of the Al Sabah family that has ruled Kuwait for nearly 200 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption in some editions yesterday about a demonstration at Community Board 3 in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the board chairman. He is Luis Soler.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bears Vice President Quits
nytimes_articles.abstract: BILL TOBIN, the Chicago Bears' vice president of player personnel, resigned yesterday, citing differences with the team's management. "When I saw that there were going to be changes I couldn't go along with on how to structure the personnel office and how it should be operated, it was time to make my exit," Tobin said.   Tobin said he had received several signals from team officials that they wanted him out of the post. He said his future in football is up in the air.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: Playoffs to determine the 1993 United States teams for world championship play in Chile in September began here this morning. After 16 deals in the open series, the Reisinger team, including David Berkowitz, Larry Cohen and Sam Lev from the New York area, were exactly tied with the Vanderbilt team, which includes Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y. In the other match the Spingold team, headed by Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., led by 15 imps against the Grand National team, one from the Chicago area.   In the women's series, the team including Gail Greenberg of Manhattan led by 54 against one with Judge Amalya Kearse of Manhattan; Rozanne Pollack of Englewood, N.J., and her team led by 9 against Karen Allison of Jersey City and hers, and the squad with Kerri Shuman of Manhattan led by 24 against Renee Mancuso of Los Angeles and her team.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Political Spouse
nytimes_articles.abstract: The only time I saw Pat Nixon get testy with her husband was when he invited their Irish setter, King Timahoe, to climb up on a newly recovered couch in his White House office; it offended her frugal soul and she let Richard Nixon know it.   What I did not know at the time was their experience with another dog. During the two years in the 1940's when Nixon was trying to get her to marry him, she took care of his Irish setter, also named King; the young naval officer gave her a small china statue of an Irish setter by way of thanks. Years later, in the White House, she put that piece on the desk in his private office, where he kept it as a reminder of the old days.

nytimes_articles.headline: But How About Rex?: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: In your Rex Morgan strip, I don't like the look of this doctor, Keith, back from South Africa. He's got a bad haircut, a limp sense of humor and he doesn't even know how to spell hamster! June Gale should stick with Spiro.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reaction to Harazin Is a Very Mixed Bag
nytimes_articles.abstract: As Al Harazin's legacy bumbled toward another loss yesterday afternoon, there was a mixed reaction at Shea Stadium to the Tuesday resignation of the Mets' general manager.   Howard Johnson and John Franco, though not necessarily critical of the departed general manager, saw positives in the change. Other players like Bret Saberhagen and Chico Walker expressed remorse at Harazin's fate. And Manager Dallas Green didn't think his players really had an opinion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bart Without Cable TV: Nothing but a T-Shirt
nytimes_articles.abstract: Children's Discretion Advised: Some parts of the following article may contain subject matter unsuitable for parents who believe your grades would be higher if you watched less television.   A COUPLE of years ago, Megan and Weston Cadwell desperately wanted Bart Simpson T-shirts. After all, it was the height of "The Simpsons" television fame and lots of the Cadwell twins' friends had the shirts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Portugal and Bosnia : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "It's Their Balkan Quarrel" (Opinion, June 2) by José Cutileiro: .If the European Community had adopted the same dismissive attitude toward Portugal during its time of troubles in the 1970s, I wonder where Mr. Cutileiro would b

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz; A Crowd-Pleasing Kenny G
nytimes_articles.abstract: If the music of the popular soprano saxophonist Kenny G is lightweight and shamelessly crowd-pleasing, it is also hard to dislike. This 36-year-old instrumentalist from Seattle, whose full name is Kenny Gorelick, has invented his own brand of amiable mood music. Ceaselessly melodic and gentle in spirit (even when driven by a rhythm-and-blues backbeat), it evokes idyllic Pacific Ocean vistas, and birds curling and dipping into picture-postcard sunsets.    The versatility and sweetness of Mr. Gorelick's tone poems have made him the best-selling solo instrumentalist in the country. His newest album, "Breathless" (Arista), teems with wistfully sunny melodies burbled in settings that find a natural blend of pop romanticism, jazz-fusion energy and New Age ambiance.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: The Victoria Sinks : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - Since the loss of H.M.S. Captain no naval disaster has been fraught with as much horror and grief as the loss of the flagship Victoria, which, with her Admiral, Sir George Tyron, and 442 officers and men, now lies at the bottom of the Mediterrane

nytimes_articles.headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
nytimes_articles.abstract: Larry Collins, whose latest book is "Black Eagles," is reading "Fanny Stevenson: Entre Passion et Liberté," by Alexandra Lapierre. ."This biography of the wife of Robert Louis Stevenson breathes new life into the old canard

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Balanchine Celebration Lightens Up
nytimes_articles.abstract: Entering the home stretch, the New York City Ballet's very serious Balanchine Celebration turned to humor on Tuesday night. The festival's final week at the New York State Theater opened with a spirited revival of "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme."   It is easy to see why this frolicsome ballet is too slight to become a repertory staple. Based on an episode in Moliere's "Bourgeois Gentilhomme," the work is essentially a divertissement that pretends to have an outline of a plot. Balanchine, despite such pitfalls, choreographed three versions of "Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme": in 1932, 1944 and 1979, on commission for the New York City Opera. The last staging was conceived as a vehicle for Rudolf Nureyev, who portrayed the 17th-century parvenu attempting to learn the arts of a gentleman.

nytimes_articles.headline: The 4 Percent's Solution Isn't Latest N.F.L. Pact
nytimes_articles.abstract: Early next week in Washington, the power brokers for the National Football League and the N.F.L. Players Association will join for what qualifies as a historic moment in league history: the ceremonial signing of the league's new seven-year collective bargaining agreement with its players.   "I don't know exactly how much pomp and circumstance to expect from the N.F.L," joked Jim Quinn, the lead attorney for the players association. "In the other sports we do these things every few years and it's not such a big deal. This is the N.F.L., you know."

nytimes_articles.headline: Agency Faults New York in Bus Crash
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York State Department of Transportation shares responsibility with Federal highway officials and the driver-owner of a bus involved in an accident last July that killed six people and injured 48, the National Transportation Safety Board found today.   The Brooklyn-based charter bus was carrying families to an amusement park when it veered out of control going down a steep hill in Vernon, N.J. The bus collided with two cars and burst into flames.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-12  THE END OF A JAPANESE ORDER  Declaring the governing Liberal Democratic Party a corrupt relic of the cold war, former Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata proclaimed the end of Japan's postwar political order amid signs that his new party of Liberal Democratic defectors may also force the breakup of the largest opposition movement, the Socialists.  A1  Japanese turmoil had been brewing for years.  A7

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Won't Send Troops To Seek Croats' Bodies
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States has rejected a request by the United Nations to send military engineers to help dig up evidence of possible war crimes in Croatia because Washington does not want to put American soldiers at risk, State and Defense Department officials said today.   Instead, the Administration will donate $180,000 in medical supplies and equipment, including body bags, surgical instruments, hand tools and cleaning solvents, to Physicians for Human Rights. The group, based in Boston, is aiding an investigation into what is believed to be one of the worst massacres in the Balkan war.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hypocrisy on Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The United Nations human rights conference in Vienna has focused attention on a longstanding debate: Who decides what constitutes a human right? The U.S. is on shaky ground in that debate.

Some governments argue that cultural variations justify different interpretations of fundamental human rights. They say basic guarantees of due process and democracy are Western concepts that are imposed on the third world without its consent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Panel Takes First Steps, Modestly, in Closing Bases
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the first of a set of decisions that will cause economic disruption in scores of communities nationwide, a Presidential commission voted today to close one small Army installation and shrink another Army base but spared two big bases in New Jersey and Alabama.   Beginning today through Sunday, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission is deciding to close, shrink or spare 88 major military bases and 150 smaller installations that in most cases are the economic engines in their regions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Split in Japan's Ruling Party Is Rearranging Political Map
nytimes_articles.abstract: Declaring the governing Liberal Democratic Party a corrupt relic of the cold war, former Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata proclaimed the end of Japan's postwar political order today amid signs that his new party of Liberal Democratic defectors may also force the break-up of the largest opposition movement, the Socialists.   Mr. Hata, who led a walkout of 44 Liberal Democratic members of Parliament on Tuesday, announced the formation of the new party at a raucous news conference this afternoon, saying the aging leaders of the ruling party had no more than "a hope and a fantasy" of continuing their 38 years of one-party dominance. The conference was held in a packed hotel function room, overheated with banks of television lights. Security was unusually tight.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Year Later, Death's Echoes
nytimes_articles.abstract: More than a year has passed since the February morning when Khalil Sumpter pulled a gun from under his jacket, fatally shot two fellow students and turned Thomas Jefferson High School into a symbol of the ruthless penetration of street violence into the lives of young people and the places once considered safe havens.   Since then, there have been marches for peace, congressional hearings on youth violence, efforts to lobby for gun control and added security measures, like extra guards and metal detectors, installed at New York City's public schools. And Thomas Jefferson, or "Jeff" as the Brooklyn school is known, has made peace with itself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Games Museum Opens
nytimes_articles.abstract: With the two-time figure skating gold medalist, KATARINA WITT, lighting the flame, Olympic leaders yesterday inaugurated a $65 million museum in Lausanne, Switzerland. The museum, a five-story, white marble building set on the side of a hill overlooking Lake Geneva, is devoted to the history of the ancient and modern Games.   Twenty German protesters were detained in two minor incidents for throwing eggs and shouting slogans against Berlin's bid to stage the 2000 Summer Olympics.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: After months of speculation that he was being courted by ABC, ED BRADLEY has decided to remain at CBS, it was announced yesterday by ERIC OBER, president of CBS News, and HOWARD STRINGER, president of the CBS Broadcast Group.    Mr. Bradley, who became a correspondent on "60 Minutes" in 1981, has also been the anchor of "Street Stories," the news magazine that began broadcasting in January 1992. He has decided to leave that program, which will go off the air in the fall to be reformulated and renamed, said Tom Goodman, a spokesman for CBS News.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: FEWER SUMMER JOBS EXPECTED   With a belated package of Federal funding about to be approved by Congress, government agencies and community groups in New York City are gearing up for a summer jobs program for teen-agers that promises fewer jobs and shorter periods of employment than in recent years. A1. NEW YORK CITY  EMPIRE SUSPENDS FINANCIAL OFFICER   The board of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield suspended the company's chief financial officer without pay because of questions about his role in submitting misleading figures to state officials. The board had previously put the official, Jerry Weissman, on a paid leave after finding that the figures were in error. B5.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It's the most exciting thing that's happened in -- geez -- maybe ever, in mathematics." -- DR. LEONARD ADELMAN, of the Univeristy of Southern California, on the discovery of a proof for a 350-year-old mathematical theorem.  [ A1:2. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: SYMBOL OF POWER: RULING MEXICO CITY
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a half-step toward meeting demands for greater democracy in the hemisphere's biggest metropolis, the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has proposed a new form of government for Mexico City.   The country's main opposition parties objected almost as soon as the proposal was presented late Tuesday, saying it would reserve inordinate local power to the President and to the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has governed for 64 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Tuesday about the adoption of New Jersey's budget misstated the scope of a change proposed in the income tax on nonresidents, and a correction in this space yesterday repeated the error. The proposal, which would change the method of computing the tax, would affect all nonresidents who work in New Jersey except those from Pennsylvania; it is not directed just at New Yorkers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Changing Channels: Letterman Prepares For Last NBC Show
nytimes_articles.abstract: After all the jokes about General Electric toasters and pinhead network executives, and after all the ill feeling about his decision to jump to CBS in August, David Letterman is still approaching his final performance on NBC with "a bit of nostalgia" that he said was likely to produce "an emotional outpouring."   The very last "Late Night With David Letterman," concluding a run of more than 11 years on NBC, will be broadcast tomorrow night. As the star prepared this week for his exit from the stage at Studio 6A in the General Electric Building, he said: "I absolutely will have many important things to say and I will have many people to thank. Maybe we'll just have one solo spotlight on a stool downstage and I'll just sit there and sob for an hour." 'Wonderful Surprise' Guest    That is not the real format for Friday's finale, of course. Instead, one of the show's most popular guests, Tom Hanks, is scheduled, along with a guest Mr. Letterman described as "a wonderful surprise." He said it was a guest who would not agree to come on if the name was revealed in advance. But he added, "It is someone in my life who has meant a great deal and it is someone who has never been booked on the show before."

nytimes_articles.headline: Contenders Are Interested in Obtaining Mets' Tanana
nytimes_articles.abstract: Frank Tanana did not do enough to win a game for the Mets yesterday at Shea Stadium. Tanana also did nothing to hurt his trade value. Such are the kinds of calculations that will color the rest of the season for the Mets.   The interest in Tanana from other clubs is real. The Mets have fielded more than a couple of calls asking about the 39-year-old left-hander, and according to one executive in baseball, there is a standing offer on the table that the Mets could act on at any time in the next week. The other club is believed to be the Chicago White Sox.

nytimes_articles.headline: Home Video
nytimes_articles.abstract: Closed-Captioning    Beginning next week, television sets with screens larger than 13 inches manufactured for sale in the United States must have a built-in decoder to unscramble the closed-caption part of the signal that provides dialogue and other information about the soundtrack for the deaf and hard of hearing.    The integrated decoder, which is activated with the flip of a switch on the set, has several creative and commercial advantages over the separate decoders now in use.

nytimes_articles.headline: Flying With Bad Vibes
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Several airlines have alienated -- that is, further alienated -- important passengers by banning the use of laptop computers for part of any flight. The airlines say pilots have complained that their navigational instruments have been inexplicably disrupted at times.

A Federal Aviation Administration study didn't turn up any evidence confirming the suspicion, but the airlines say they want to be safe.

nytimes_articles.headline: How House Panel Is Persuaded to Retreat
nytimes_articles.abstract: The House subcommittee that helps to support the District of Columbia's government thought it had found a painless way to funnel money to the District: it would force a giant federally sponsored mortgage corporation to pay local income taxes.    Not surprisingly, the corporation, known as Fannie Mae, fought back. The federally chartered concern, which is the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, lobbied vigorously to defeat the proposal, which was withdrawn today.

nytimes_articles.headline: Timetable for Deciding on Closings
nytimes_articles.abstract: Here are the dates by which the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, the President and Congress are expected to act on closings of American military bases:   JULY 1.  The commission submits its final recommendations to President Clinton.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mets Prepared to Give McIlvaine Blank Check
nytimes_articles.abstract: There is no longer any reason to read too deeply for meaning in the statements out of Shea Stadium: Joe McIlvaine is going to be the next general manager of the Mets. The club has told him that no baseball decisions will be made before he either says yes or no to the job, and that if he wants to accept the title and remain in California indefinitely, he can do so with absolute veto power over all baseball affairs.   "He is a man who will fill a need we have, and he is a man that we know to be of great honesty, integrity and ability," Fred Wilpon, one of the owners of the Mets, said yesterday. "He doesn't have to pick up. He's been in the National League. He will be right in step."

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Suspects Are Arrested In Art Theft On Park Ave.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two men were arrested yesterday in the theft of more than $1 million in 20th-century paintings and other valuables from a Park Avenue apartment, the authorities said.   Six paintings were recovered after a U.S. Postal Service agent posing as a "wealthy European art dealer" told the suspects in April 1992 that he was interested in buying the stolen works, said Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney.

nytimes_articles.headline: Goodbye, Adirondacks?
nytimes_articles.abstract: This is the moment of truth for the Adirondacks. The future of New York's greatest public natural resource is at stake.   In the next few days, the Republican majority of the State Senate will decide whether one man's zealotry to kill the Adirondack Park will prevail.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Widens Investigation Into Bonds And Trenton
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has widened its investigation into the dealings of two New Jersey bond firms whose owners have political links to Gov. Jim Florio, subpoenaing records from a host of county and municipal agencies and asking some bond dealers for detailed information about their political contributions.   Officials in three counties -- Gloucester, Passaic and Mercer -- confirmed reports today that they had been served subpoenas for documents relating to bond deals involving Armacon Securities and Consolidated Financial Management.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ban Anachronistic Arms Tests
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ever since World War II the planet has lived with the threat of nuclear war. Thirty years ago, the Limited Test Ban Treaty drove U.S., Soviet and British nuclear testing underground. But a total ban on nuclear tests has eluded the world's grasp. President Clinton is now in a position to help achieve that goal.    During his campaign, Mr. Clinton called for "a new national security policy equal to the challenges of the post-cold-war era." Testing new nuclear arms was not among the challenges he cited. Stopping nuclear proliferation was.

nytimes_articles.headline: Team Limits Recommended
nytimes_articles.abstract: A National Collegiate Athletic Association committee looking into the financial condition of college athletics yesterday recommended limits on the size of football squads, 105 players for Division 1-A and 90 for Division 1-AA. Recommendations from the special committee, headed by Big Ten Commissioner JIM DELANY, will go to the N.C.A.A. Presidents Commission, which meets in Kansas City next week.   The report by the 22-member committee said its work was impeded by lack of reliable and comparable data because some schools were hesitant to share financial information.

nytimes_articles.headline: To a Land Loved and Left, Sam Spiegel's Art
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the early 1920's, barely past his teen-age years and far from being able to dream that he would become an Academy Award-winning producer, Sam Spiegel dug ditches and sewers as a "young pioneer" in Palestine.   He didn't make it.   Life as a "drainage expert," as he later described it, was not for him, and before long he left. Eventually, he found his way to Hollywood, a short, domineering man who made his share of enemies over the years but also filled more than his quota of film masterpieces, including "The African Queen," "On the Waterfront," "The Bridge on the River Kwai" and "Lawrence of Arabia."

nytimes_articles.headline: When Politics Go Bizarre: Council Member's Arrest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Samuel Horwitz, a City Councilman from Brooklyn, planned to attend a kindergarten graduation ceremony yesterday for the son of a constituent. But Mr. Horwitz never made it into the auditorium. Instead, the 74-year-old Democratic Councilman was arrested, handcuffed and taken to the police precinct station house in a turbulent morning that underscored how bizarre New York City politics can be.   School officials said Mr. Horwitz had been arrested because he insisted on entering the elementary-school auditorium even though he had no ticket, with the tickets issued only to parents.

nytimes_articles.headline: Let's Look Again at This Fernandez Legacy
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "A Fernandez Legacy to City Schools" (editorial, June 12) fails to reflect the reality in New York City schools. As Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez did bring us the concept of school-based management, which he supposedly designed in Florida. Unfortunately, he sold his proposal from the steps of his headquarters on Livingston Street, but never allowed it to enter through the front door. His administration has been characterized by a top-down philosophy, in which no opinions were requested, few considered, and fewer yet accepted. Those of us who worked in the system under his leadership were struck by the contrast between what he said and what he did.

nytimes_articles.headline: AN ASTEROID BELT NEAR EARTH'S PATH
nytimes_articles.abstract: Scientists believe they have discovered a belt of asteroids in orbits so close to the earth's orbit that many of them are bound to hit the planet sooner or later. But fortunately, most of these space bullets are so small that they will probably explode in the earth's upper atmosphere without causing any damage or injuries on the ground.   This mixed message was reported in two papers published in today's issue of the British journal Nature. It comes a month after one asteroid, Object 93KA2, zipped past the earth only 90,000 miles away, the closest near collision ever observed. This chunk of debris, 15 feet in diameter, was far too small to create a hazard, but if it had hit the atmosphere instead of skimming past, people might have been treated to a spectacular fireworks display as it exploded.

nytimes_articles.headline: Challenges Remain in Cambodia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Despite the inaugural meeting of a constituent assembly and agreement on an interim government, the Cambodian peace process is still in a fragile state. A new constitution and a viable government have to be created before the work of the United Nations i

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Armistead Maupin, Not Dreamt Up but Inspired
nytimes_articles.abstract: Public television is taking note of Gay Pride Month with three outspoken specials concerning gay people and gay issues. Perhaps not surprisingly, two programs, profiles of American writers, were produced for the BBC: "Larry Kramer," broadcast last weekend on PBS, and "Armistead Maupin Is a Man I Dreamt Up," on PBS tonight at 10. Sunday at 11 P.M. on PBS, there's "Lives in the Balance: The Lesbian and Gay Movement in the 1990's," a documentary centered on April's march on Washington by gay men and lesbians, their friends and their families numbering about 300,000, as reported by the United States Park Police.    "Larry Kramer" captures an unusually balanced portrait of the novelist ("Faggots") and playwright ("The Normal Heart," "The Destiny of Me"), who is best known for raging against an American establishment he accuses of neglecting "the 20th-century plague, AIDS."

nytimes_articles.headline: To Turn the Tables (folo) : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding the decision in the case of the Japanese boy: Nothing in my 20 years of living abroad had made me ashamed to be an American - until this.

nytimes_articles.headline: House Passes a Bill to Encourage Strikes
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "House Passes Bill to Ban Replacement of Strikers" (news article, June 16) incorrectly reports of H.R. 5: "The measure would apply only to companies where a labor group is recognized by the employer or the National Labor Relations Board as the exclusive representative of the workers in negotiations."

nytimes_articles.headline: Under Public Fire, Triple Crown Reconsiders Format
nytimes_articles.abstract: Racing officials, reacting to public concern over fatal injuries to star horses in the Preakness Stakes last month and the Belmont Stakes three weeks ago, are exploring a landmark change that would provide more spacing between the races in the Triple Crown series.   No new format has been developed, but one racing executive reported that one sequence under discussion was this: The Kentucky Derby would still be run on the first Saturday in May, but the Preakness would be run one month (instead of two weeks) later and the Belmont Stakes one month (instead of three weeks) after that. So, instead of three demanding races in five weeks' time, the races would be spread over eight weeks' time.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tournament Won't Pay Price
nytimes_articles.abstract: NICK FALDO, BERNHARD LANGER and IAN WOOSNAM wanted too much money to show up, according to organizers of the French Open, so they will be missing when the tournament begins today in Saint Quentin en Yvelines. However, six of the top 10 money winners on the European PGA Tour are entered.   "Faldo asked for $150,000, Langer and Woosnam for $95,000," said LIONEL PROVOST, the president of Promogolf, one of the organizers. "These are obscene figures to be throwing around with millions of Europeans out of work. This year we decided to call a halt to the money madness."

nytimes_articles.headline: Cutback in U.S. Funds to Reduce Summer Jobs for New York Youths
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a belated package of Federal financing about to be approved by Congress, government agencies and community groups in New York City are gearing up for a summer jobs program for teen-agers that promises fewer jobs and shorter periods of employment than in recent years.   The Federal program, a cornerstone of the nation's efforts to give poor young people their first exposure to the workaday world, is more critical than usual this year in New York, where unemployment among young people has recently soared.

nytimes_articles.headline: Zephyr Journal; Guiding a Roar Across the Heartland
nytimes_articles.abstract: Inside the California Zephyr, Amtrak's transcontinental train between Chicago and Oakland, Calif., America is on vacation. It's a full house. School is out and there are a lot of families on board, maybe 300 passengers all told, and they're exchanging stories with strangers about the weather in their home towns, coddling babies, visiting the snack bar, passing judgment on the views of Rush Limbaugh.   There are a lot of video cameras pointed out the windows and almost everyone, it seems, is carrying a paperback by John Grisham, including a Baptist clergyman from Springfield, Ill., named John Grisham.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Clinton Beats the Haitians
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court has upheld the Bush-Clinton policy of taking to the high seas to force fleeing Haitians to return home. In doing so, it has given the executive branch a legal victory and a moral black eye.    Revolted by episodes of forced repatriation of political refugees, the United Nations and Congress prohibited the practice -- but not, says the Court, on the high seas. Why didn't the law mention the high seas? Probably because the lawmakers "may not have contemplated that any nation would gather fleeing refugees and return them to the one country they had desperately sought to escape."

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart yesterday listing last week's top 10 television shows included erroneous ratings supplied by A. C. Nielsen & Company. A corrected chart appears today on page C20.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Mexican Jobs Ease U.S. Burden
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Reaganomics, With a Mexican Accent," (Op-Ed, June 11), Michael Lind accuses President Clinton of confusion because he supports revitalizing the economy and the North America Free Trade Agreement, but Mr. Lind's arguments are confused.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fresh Air in the Air
nytimes_articles.abstract: The air that circulates through jumbo jets isn't as fresh as it used to be. To economize on fuel, the newer planes change cabin air less frequently than older models -- every six minutes or longer, versus every three minutes. The effect on health and comfort is not known with any certainty, but the risk is such that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta are investigating whether infected passengers can transmit tuberculosis.   Broader study of all possible effects is needed as well. Passengers and crews have complained of headaches, nausea, double vision and -- not least -- the discomfort of less-than-fresh air.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pretty Swing, Pretty Streak, Ugly Ending
nytimes_articles.abstract: The prettiest swing in baseball had produced the prettiest hitting streak of the season, but it all vanished in an ugly manner tonight after 26 games for John Olerud. No line drive, no deep fly ball, not even a bunt single. The streak ended on an artifical turf chopper. Ugly.   After 95 at-bats, 40 hits, 8 homers and a .421 average, it was Olerud against Steve Howe in the eighth inning of a 4-3 game. There were men on first and third so Olerud could have extended his hitting streak to 27 and also helped the Jays win and move into a first-place tie. He did neither. He hit a chopper.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unlicensed Driver Arrested for 420 Suspensions
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Staten Island man who was stopped for a minor traffic infraction on Tuesday was arrested when a police officer discovered that he had 420 suspensions on his driving record, even though he had no license at all, the police said yesterday.   The driver was identified as Paul Gagliardo, a 26-year-old auto parts deliveryman. The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles said the suspensions arose from his failure to answer summonses given on 131 occasions for one or more traffic violations over a seven-year period.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stewart Comes Back From Life's Standing 8
nytimes_articles.abstract: Of all the fighters he belted to the canvas in a career that began with 24 straight knockouts, Alex Stewart defines himself by the moment he was knocked flat on his back -- but got up.   Even though Stewart eventually lost that fight 14 months ago by decision to George Foreman, it turned around a career that was foundering.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918:British Progress : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: CAIRO - The British troops have made rapid advances in Mesopotamia on the way from Bagdad to Mossoul. General Marshall has advanced beyond Kerkouk, more than 164 miles from Bagdad. In consequence, however, of the difficulties of supplies in a region which

nytimes_articles.headline: It's Shave and Volley As Agassi Advances
nytimes_articles.abstract: A little bit fiction, a little bit superstition and, according to him, a little more aerodynamic now that he has taken drastic depilatory measures on everything but his scalp, defending Wimbledon champion Andre Agassi's moves -- and midriff -- are getting smoother all the time.   The Las Vegan, whose mere presence at this staid site creates chaos reminiscent of Beatlemania, left himself just five matches away from untold personal glory this afternoon by eliminating Portugal's Joao Cunha-Silva from the second round, 5-7, 6-3, 6-2, 6-0.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Reports Setback On Russian Aid Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration said a $4 billion international fund it proposed to help state enterprises in Russia convert to private businesses would have to be scaled back because Japan and West European allies were too squeezed for cash to join.   "We are doing some serious arm-twisting" to save the plan, a senior Administration official said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Signed Jimmy Walker, pitcher, and assigned him to Albany of the South Atlantic League.   BOSTON RED SOX -- Named Al Nipper pitching coach for Fort Myers of the Gulf Coast League. Placed Luis Rivera, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 21.

nytimes_articles.headline: Science Needs the Supercollider
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Atom Smasher Is Super Nonsense" (Op-Ed June 17), John Lukacs attacks not only the supercollider in Texas, but also the enterprise of particle physics. One can debate how scarce public funds should be spent on research, but this nonsensical article shows a shocking ignorance and a dangerous antiscience bias.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins Is Questioned On Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: The state official preparing a long-awaited report on the racial violence in Crown Heights met with Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday to question him further about his administration's handling of the disturbances.   But the official said he would not speed up his inquiry despite a call by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly for the quick release of the findings and the issue's growing prominence in the New York City mayoral campaign.

nytimes_articles.headline: Let There Be No Solingens in France
nytimes_articles.abstract: Newly in office, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur said that he wanted to make France "an example." Ten weeks later, what sort of example is it? .The new majority has made the questions of nationality and foreigners' rights its urgent prioritie

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Reforms' That Split Japan's Political World
nytimes_articles.abstract: The turmoil that has suddenly upset Japan's political system is due to a number of problems and rivalries building up for years, but the immediate trigger was a dispute over cleaning up the scandal-plagued electoral system.    Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's Government staked its future on passing political reform legislation, which many regard as essential to restoring public trust in politicians.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Suspends Aid
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration called the Nigerian military's decision to cancel the election results "outrageous" today and suspended America's non-relief aid to the West African country.   In addition, the United States began talks with European countries and other African nations about concerted actions against Nigeria, including the possibility of halting joint aid.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jail Threat Ends 13-Month Sit-In To Save Church
nytimes_articles.abstract: A group of 45 middle-age men and woman walked out of St. Joseph's Church today, ending a 13-month sit-in, after their Bishop obtained a court order to evict them from the 65-year-old building, which he says is unsafe.   The parishioners, who had taken turns sleeping on the pews and floors for more than a year to protest the closing of the church, left only after their long legal battle with the Diocese of Worcester came to a close. Judge Thomas Connolly of Superior Court found them in contempt of court earlier in the day and threatened them with fines or jail sentences if they did not leave. The judge said he was saddened to have to intervene in what he called an "unbelievably unfortunate and sad situation."

nytimes_articles.headline: Cornwall Village Gets a Tate Gallery Branch
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nestled into the cliffs overlooking Porthmeor Beach in this tiny fishing village in the farthest corner of Cornwall is the brand new Tate St. Ives, a pristine white structure that politely defers to the sea. Within, there is a selection of art from the English artists who belong to the St. Ives School, selected from the holdings of the Tate Gallery in London.    The opening of the $4.95 million museum has not been without considerable fanfare, in the hope of improving the fortunes of St. Ives, an economically depressed area with an artistically rich history.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Judge Upholds Search of a Suspect In Bombing Inquiry
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday upheld the search of a man arrested as part of the investigation into the World Trade Center bombing, saying detectives had information linking him to the explosion.   The defendant, Ibrahim A. Elgabrowny, who is not accused of aiding in the blast itself, contended that he was assaulted by members of a Federal anti-terrorist squad and then illegally searched outside his apartment at 57 Prospect Park Southwest in Brooklyn on March 4. His arrest came one week after the the Feb. 26 explosion, which killed six people and injured more than 1,000.

nytimes_articles.headline: Arocha Gets as Close to Cuba as He Can
nytimes_articles.abstract: Along with Nike and Radio Mambi, a Miami radio station, Rene Arocha paid for 500 general-admission tickets to tonight's St. Louis Cardinals-Florida Marlins game. Another 35 friends and hundreds of well-wishers were among the 37,936 fans who came through the turnstiles at Joe Robbie Stadium.   Arocha, the Cardinals' rookie pitcher who defected from Cuba nearly two years ago and has made Miami his adopted hometown, "just wanted to give a thanks to the community," according to Gus Dominguez, his agent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; Young Saxophonist Is Almost an Old Pro
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the middle of "Echos," his second tune at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night, the young tenor saxophonist Josh Redman started to improvise. Not the kind of improvisation in which a musician puts together preplanned phrases and memorized ideas, but the rarer sort that comes from somewere else.   It's unfettered creativity, where ideas immediately become music; musicians often chalk it up to a higher power. Mr. Redman had that freedom. He was honking, and breaking up lines with staccato phrases, scribbling lines furiously and jumping octaves, laying thought over thought until dense pools of notes made up a musical landscape. Then, by running off a classically balanced be-bop line, he would escape.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ex-Officers Shot in Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two retired police officers were shot and wounded in Maspeth, Queens, last night during what appears to have been a robbery by an undetermined number of men, the police said. The incident occurred shortly before 10 P.M., when the two men, who were working for Copstat Security Company, approached a Chemical Bank at 49th Street and Grand Avenue to make a bank drop, said Officer Andrew McInnis, a police spokesman. The two men, who were not immediately identified, were listed in stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital. He said officers were told that a gray van had been seen fleeing the scene.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bullets Get Duckworth for Grant
nytimes_articles.abstract: KEVIN DUCKWORTH, who went from All-Star center to disgruntled reserve in Portland, was traded by the Trail Blazers to the Washington Bullets for forward HARVEY GRANT. The Bullets also acquired "other considerations" neither club would identify.

nytimes_articles.headline: Amelia Earhart Doesn't Go Uncelebrated; Also in California
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Lynn Sherr and Jurate Kazickas bemoan the lack of women on a pedestal (Op-Ed, June 14). But decrying the lack of a statue for Amelia Earhart is Eastern chauvinism. A few miles from my Burbank home, the grounds of North Hollywood's Public Library boast a very imposing statue of the dauntless Amelia Earhart.

nytimes_articles.headline: China:The Regions' New Strength Saps the Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: Economists have finally recognized that China's economy is one of the world's largest. But before China becomes number one - which will probably happen within the next generation - it is time to recognize another emerging reality about China: The power o

nytimes_articles.headline: Extend Card Coverage : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding the report "American Express Acts To Open Airlines Plan To All Its Cardholders" (June 11): .The action to be taken by American Express to end the anomaly that excludes cardholders outside the United States from its Membership Miles

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday about American auto makers' operations in Europe misattributed an estimate that the Ford Motor Company would lose $500 million in Europe this year. Ford has said it expects to be unprofitable in Europe in 1993, but the amount was the estimate of a financial analyst.

nytimes_articles.headline: San Pedro de Tiquina Journal; Landlocked Navy's Dream Is to Go Down to Sea
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senior officers here at Bolivia's largest naval base, tucked along a peninsula that juts into Lake Titicaca, admit they would prefer life on the high seas.   The mission of their 250 cadets, many of whom do not know how to swim, is to police the 150-mile length of the lake with five tiny patrol boats, hoping to catch the occasional Shining Path guerrilla passing by boat from Peru to Bolivia.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Man of Letters, Some Even Printable
nytimes_articles.abstract: I've been savaged, bloodied and insulted, preached to, scorned and condescended to. I feel like a soccer referee who is fleeing angry fans. I did the unthinkable: I admitted to having snoozed during ABC's telecast of the United States-Germany game on June 13 during U.S. Cup '93 and then had the gumption to remark that soccer does not play well on TV.   I made no friends by suggesting that my posterior hurt from watching action that was unbroken by commercials. Comparing soccer with basketball on TV won me little acclaim.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yonkers School Game or Sex Abuse?
nytimes_articles.abstract: After nine elementary school students were charged last week with sexual abuse of a classmate, school officials tried to explain what happened by saying the children were involved in a game of "let's play rape" that got out of hand.   That characterization of the events June 11 in the schoolyard of Public School 23 has caused as almost much consternation and controversy as the episode itself.

nytimes_articles.headline: N.B.A. Investigating Esquinas
nytimes_articles.abstract: FREDERICK B. LACEY, a former Federal court judge and United States attorney, will handle the National Basketball Association's investigation of RICHARD ESQUINAS, a San Diego businessman who claims to have won more than $1 million in golf bets from the Chicago Bulls' MICHAEL JORDAN. According to a league spokesperson, Lacey will soon meet with Esquinas's representatives, to discuss the allegations Esquinas made in a self-published book released earlier this month. The league also wants to determine whether Esquinas has any other gambling connections.
