nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Films Inspired by a Master of Literary Delicacy
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Henry James's play "Guy Domville" was produced in 1895, he appeared on stage for an opening-night bow and was hit with jeers, boos and catcalls that drowned out his friends' polite applause. It was not the last time an audience decided James wasn't much of a showman, and he soon returned to what he did best: writing novels and tales of exquisite subtlety. But he always longed for large public acclaim, and finally, curiously, belatedly, James found his mass audience on film.   There is nothing Hollywood would call high-concept in his fiction. His characters' most dramatic moments often exist in what they see or think or sense, or think they possibly might have seen or sensed. Isabel Archer's wedding in "The Portrait of a Lady" is an absolute nonevent that takes place between chapters, nothing compared to the quiet moment when she realizes her husband has deceived her. And James's career is filled with heroes whose most energetic action is running from their own emotions. Yet film makers as different as William Wyler, Francois Truffaut, Jacques Rivette and James Ivory have been gloriously inspired by James, in unpredictable ways.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reno and F.B.I. Chief Meet But He's Still Got His Job
nytimes_articles.abstract: The protracted discussion about William S. Sessions' tenure as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation took another awkward turn today when Attorney General Janet Reno met again with Mr. Sessions but apparently failed to reach a decision on his fate.   Although the latest meeting was private, F.B.I. headquarters hummed with speculation about the outcome. Officially, spokesmen at the bureau and the Justice Department would not comment on the meeting.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Photography; How the Old West Was, and Wasn't
nytimes_articles.abstract: With its colorful cast of cowboys and Indians, settlers and gunslingers, farmers and ranchers, the drama of the Western expansion continues to resonate in the American psyche. Four current photography shows, in fact, deal with the subject, as both fact and fiction.   As these shows make clear, even the earliest photographs of the land beyond the Missouri were shaped by distinct attitudes, which determined not only what was depicted, but also what form the pictures took. David Levinthal's explicitly staged images are just particularly blatant examples of the way pictures of the West have long been influenced by the preconceptions of its photographers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Loving Portrait of a Director's Roots
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Jacquot" was shown as part of the 1991 New York Film Festival under its original title, "Jacquot de Nantes." Here are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 25, 1991. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at Lincoln Plaza Cinemas.   Agnes Varda, who made her first feature, "Cleo From 5 to 7," in 1961, remains one of the most long-lived, productive and difficult-to-categorize directors associated with France's New Wave.

nytimes_articles.headline: LINKED TO FUGITIVE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prime Minister John Major's Government was dealt another blow today as the Minister for Northern Ireland resigned in a burgeoning scandal over a fugitive businessman with close ties to the Conservative Party.   The minister, Michael Mates, was the target of critical news coverage for two weeks, ever since it was learned that he and other Conservative Party members attempted to intercede on behalf of the businessman, Asil Nadir.

nytimes_articles.headline: There's Kent at Third, 90 Feet From Norfolk
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeff Kent's demotion to the minors is not certain. It is, however, under active consideration by the Mets. The infielder clearly needs to find a permanent position, and he definitely requires playing every day at that position to develop into a reliable part of any puzzle the Mets put together for 1994.   Al Harazin's resignation may have cleared the final obstacle to sending Kent to Class AAA Norfolk, for with the general manager gone, there is no political fallout for conceding that the David Cone trade of last August is at its very best a very delayed success. Kent and center fielder Ryan Thompson were acquired from Toronto in exchange for Cone, and Thompson was returned to the minors after less than a month with the Mets this season.

nytimes_articles.headline: Runs in the Ruins: Blue Jays Bury Kamieniecki
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was not a good night to be Buck Showalter. His eyes were puffy, his throat was sore and he looked as if he might not make it through the game.   It was a worse night to be Scott Kamieniecki. His eyes were bulging and his throat was unfurling profanities after the Toronto Blue Jays insured that he would not make it beyond the third inning.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reporter's Notebook; Preening Perot Likes Ruffling Feathers at the Edge of the Fray
nytimes_articles.abstract: Racing up and down the sidelines at major events, flaunting a finely honed heckle that draws belly laughs even as it unnerves the opposition, Ross Perot is the San Diego Chicken of politics. And sure enough, as the Donkeys and Elephants squared off in the Senate this afternoon for the big budget battle, Mr. Perot posted himself right at the edge of the legislative arena, feathers flying.   Flanked by about 100 supporters of his group, United We Stand America, Mr. Perot presided over what he called the preliminary delivery to Congress of petitions, said to be signed by 2.5 million people, demanding that lawmakers cut Federal spending before they raise taxes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Inquiry Said to Cite Empire's Own Errors As Cause of Its Woes
nytimes_articles.abstract: United States Senate investigators have decided that the financial problems of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer, are largely a result of its own mismanagement and not unfair competition.   Investigators for the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations have found that Empire's management problems are so chronic and deep-seated that they have rendered it incapable of performing the basic tasks of an insurance company, according to interviews with people familiar with the subcommittee's work and those questioned by investigators.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jet-Engine Workers Accept Harsh Reality
nytimes_articles.abstract: Having reluctantly agreed to a package of work-rule changes and wage concessions, unionized workers at Pratt & Whitney reported to work here today amid a sober recognition that they had lost an unwinnable battle with a company, and an industry, mired in recession.   The workers, faced with a virtual certainty that the jet-engine maker would move at least 2,000 jobs to lower-cost plants in Maine and Georgia, voted by a ratio of 4 to 3 on Wednesday to accept concessions that once would have been considered unthinkable: no wage increases for two years and up to $2 in hourly wage cuts if productivity does not improve. An Incentive Package    By accepting the Pratt & Whitney proposal, the workers put the final pieces in place for an unusual incentive package in which Connecticut will provide the company with $32 million in grants and tax breaks.

nytimes_articles.headline: United Colors of the Mets: Goodies Are Gathering Dust
nytimes_articles.abstract: As the New York Mets march sullenly into baseball ignominy, they will find no solace in learning that sales of their licensed goods are sinking, too.   Only six years ago, the Mets ranked first among 26 teams in retail sales of their licensed goods. The ranking fell to ninth last year, which has climbed slightly to eighth this year based on preseason sales figures that may have indicated an optimism that has now been dashed.

nytimes_articles.headline: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Links; Suspect in Bomb Plot Linked To World Trade Center Blast
nytimes_articles.abstract: Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, the 32-year-old Sudanese immigrant whom Federal authorities have placed at the center of a conspiracy to bomb the United Nations and other targets in New York City, confided to an F.B.I. informer that he had helped test the bomb for the World Trade Center blast in February, according to Federal officials.   That explosion, Mr. Siddig Ali was quoted in a Federal complaint as saying, was a message that "we can get you anytime."

nytimes_articles.headline: For Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Tar Beach'   Children's Museum of Manhattan  212 West 83d Street  Manhattan  (212) 721-1223  Recommended ages: 3 and up  Through December    "Tar Beach" is the dreamlike book by Faith Ringgold whose main character, the 8-year-old Cassie Louise Lightfoot, flies. As Cassie says, "I will always remember when the stars fell down around me and lifted me up above the George Washington Bridge."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Art Market
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lloyd's Losers' Luck   Special to The New York Times   LONDON, June 20 -- The talk here is of the auction houses' fierce competition to cash in on the financial losses that have overwhelmed thousands of Lloyd's of London investors who are being forced to sell off sometimes choice property to pay their debts. Among the "names," as these investors are called in England, are members of Parliament and titled families. Sotheby's and Christie's are vying for the salable property belonging to these individuals, who as investors in the three-century-old insurer are personally responsible for its obligations.   Lloyd's has been reporting huge losses for the last three years now, and the situation appears to be getting worse. As a result, the insurer's investors must raise cash to make the payouts on insurance policies.

nytimes_articles.headline: Azerbaijan's Parliament Votes to Strip Elected President of Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Parliament of Azerbaijan voted today to strip President Abulfez Elchibey of all his authority, after rejecting his last-minute offer to hand over most of his powers to the chairman of the Parliament, Heydar Aliyev.    Mr. Elchibey will remain in office until a Government report determines whether he is responsible for the fighting between rebels and Government troops that set off the country's two-week political crisis.

nytimes_articles.headline: Benjamin Glad to Be Back With Reed
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a family reunion of sorts, BENOIT BENJAMIN, the newest Net, was welcomed yesterday at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena by WILLIS REED, his former coach at Creighton University, who as the Nets' vice president and general manager engineered Benjamin's trade to New Jersey from the Los Angeles Lakers for SAM BOWIE on Monday. "I look at him like a son," Reed said. "I'm confident he can come in here and change some people's minds."

nytimes_articles.headline: I'm the Same Old Bob Dole
nytimes_articles.abstract: Don't worry, the "old Bob Dole" is still on the job. And I can still spot a phony deficit package a mile away.   I appreciate Alice M. Rivlin's nice comments on this page Wednesday about my record on staying tough on the Federal deficit, but I can also appreciate that as deputy budget director she is doing her best to put some happy hype on a terrible product: President Clinton's tax-infested $347 billion deficit-reduction package.

nytimes_articles.headline: TV Weekend; 'Front Page': Light News for the Small Screen
nytimes_articles.abstract: The spirit of MTV strikes again! The youngish hosts, the flashy graphics, the with-it sounds, the smart-alecky tone stamp "Front Page" as a news magazine for people who grew up on television. This offering from Fox Broadcasting, which is not in the habit of straining attention spans, bops along on the line between information and entertainment. To judge by tomorrow night's sprightly debut, the latest television news magazine will cause no loss of sleep over Bosnia or health coverage.   Ron Reagan possibly apart, the program's regular reporters -- Andria Hall, Tony Harris, Vicki Liviakis and Josh Mankiewicz -- are not household names. But all are personable, energetic and younger than Mike Wallace and Barbara Walters.

nytimes_articles.headline: At the Bar; Coming to a Theater Near You: Tom Cruise, Gene Hackman and Some Thrilled Memphis Lawyers.
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The Firm" opens next week, and millions of Americans will now be able to see what they've already read: how a young lawyer named Mitch McDeere outwits the malevolent firm for which he works. But to the lawyers of Memphis, the film promises a kick of another kind: it will be a chance to see themselves and their friends.   All of Memphis was caught up for three months last winter in the filming of the John Grisham novel about a newly minted Harvard lawyer, played by Tom Cruise, who sells himself to the highest bidder, a firm known as Bendini, Lambert & Locke, only to learn that if he sticks around the place too long he will end up as either a criminal or a corpse.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Saxophonist Re-Emerges, Invoking Coltrane's Voice
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Lloyd emerged spectacularly as a tenor saxophone virtuoso in the 1960's, preaching Coltrane to huge summer-of-love audiences. Some hailed him as the new hope of jazz, others dismissed him as Coltrane Lite. Then he dropped out of sight, isolating himself in Big Sur in California. Over the last decade he has been re-emerging as an artist of more intimate aims, seemingly more substantial as well.   At a JVC Jazz Festival event at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night, Mr. Lloyd was joined by two artists associated with the ECM label -- Bobo Stenson, a pianist, and Anders Jormin, a bassist -- together with the drummer Billy Hart. In "Blessing," the players intoned a darksome three-note motif around the minor triad, then moved elegantly into still-solemn major a few minutes in. Melodies derived from a triad figure strongly throughout, often of a classical stripe.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: Both semifinal matches were close today in the open playoffs here to decide the United States representation in the world championships in Chile in September.   In one match the Reisinger team, which includes Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., led by 29 imps against a Chicago squad that recruited Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla. He replaced Peter Nagy, who recently suffered a heart attack and had a bypass operation. Forty-eight deals of a scheduled 128 remain to be played.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about a technology-development program in Youngstown, Ohio, misidentified the people and the factory shown. The people were Henry E. Bertolini Jr., engineering manager of General Extrusions Inc., and Lee Krum, an employee; they were at the company's aluminum-extrusion plant.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Indian Tribes Get Gambling Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Issue of Indian Sovereignty Behind Gambling Case" (Law page, June 11) incorrectly states that the 1988 Indian Gaming Regulatory Act "grants tribes broad powers to issue and regulate gambling licenses."

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-10  KURDS HIT TURKISH SITES IN EUROPE  Kurdish rebels staged attacks on Turkish diplomatic missions and businesses across Europe, seizing hostages and battling the police to call attention to their struggle for independence from Turkey.  A1  Kurdish separatists propelled their message to a wider audience.  A10

nytimes_articles.headline: More Dinosaurs! Stalk On
nytimes_articles.abstract: BEAUTY and charisma are not the same thing. Bogart proved it. So did Jean-Paul Belmondo. And now Tyrannosaurus rex, a stomping, flesh-eating star of "Jurassic Park," has served notice that the dinosaurs who ruled the earth for 165 million years developed something even more precious than seven-inch incisors and armor plating: genuine star quality.   They're big and they're bad. They have attitude and edge. They're the only thing huger than Arnold. And they are undeniably here.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cliff Curtis's Grandson to Young: Win!
nytimes_articles.abstract: The grandson of CLIFF CURTIS, who set the major league pitching record for most consecutive games lost, has some advice for the player who might break it. "Keep your good sense of humor and keep your focus, and let's get a no-hitter next time out so we can keep the record in the family," CURTIS CREE of Hackensack, N.J. said. In 1910-11, Curtis lost 23 consecutive games for the Boston Braves. ANTHONY YOUNG of the New York Mets has tied the record and is scheduled to pitch on Sunday. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Whitney Names Curator For Its Next Biennial
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced yesterday that Klaus Kertess, the adjunct curator of drawings at the museum, would be in charge of its next Biennial Exhibition, which will open in the spring of 1995. The announcement comes in the final week of the museum's widely criticized 1993 Biennial, which was selected by Elizabeth Sussman, a curator at the museum.   The announcement means that the Whitney intends to continue to give one curator authority over the show, providing a distinct point of view. Until this year, the artwork for the Whitney Biennials, which began in the 1920's, was chosen by a group of the museum's curators.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bosnian Leadership Struggle Turns on Accepting Partition
nytimes_articles.abstract: A simmering quarrel within the Bosnian Government's 10-member collective leadership erupted into a full-scale power struggle today, creating new opportunities but also new difficulties for efforts to end the 14-month war in the former Yugoslav republic.   The seven members who had defied President Alija Izetbegovic by coming here for talks with Serbian and Croatian leaders on partitioning the country, declared in effect that they now constitute the legitimate government of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Professor Is the Favorite As Chancellor
nytimes_articles.abstract: Only one candidate, Bernard R. Gifford, among the 10 finalists under consideration as New York City's next schools chancellor appears to be seeking the job, has support on the board and is unburdened by debilitating factors, interviews with board members and school officials indicate.   As a result, Mr. Gifford, an education professor at the University of California at Berkeley who was a finalist in the 1988 chancellor search, has emerged as the front-runner as successive candidates have withdrawn from consideration and board members have privately voiced criticism of the others. Praise From Board Members    The surge by Mr. Gifford, who is black, appears to work to the advantage of Rudolph W. Giuliani in the racial politics of the unfolding mayoral race. Though neither candidate has expressed a preference, city and school officials have said Mayor David N. Dinkins, struggling to keep the Hispanic support that helped elect him in 1989, would like another Hispanic chancellor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Might It Help to Be a Star? Well, It Couldn't Hurt
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONCE, the Regency Hotel was Hollywood East. The hotel was crammed with visiting movie stars and studio executives who found the Regency comfortably luxurious, smoothly discreet and reasonably convenient at 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street. On top of all that, the hotel invented New York's power breakfast. Since people in Hollywood enshrine power, those breakfasts at the Regency made all the visiting producers, agents and movie executives feel as if they were just down the road at the Bel-Air Hotel.   But trends -- like studio executives -- fade. The folks from Hollywood are fickle. "They're like lemmings," said one film company executive. Another said, "Someone says the toasted bagel is better at the Mark, and they'll all move." Well, the toasted bagels are just fine at the Regency. But the hotel, while quite luxurious, has become like one of those Hollywood studios that churn out predictable, profitable and not entirely satisfying films. And the Hollywood crowd, which is never content, has been defecting, bit by bit, to the Mark, the Ritz-Carlton, the St. Regis, the Royalton and the newly opened Four Seasons.

nytimes_articles.headline: 10 Years and 5,000 Miles for a Drug Conviction
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Isaac Kirman was stopped last winter by the Israeli police for driving in reverse on a Tel Aviv street, no one received the news with more interest than a Long Island prosecutor named Mark Cohen.   It was not Mr. Kirman's driving habits that drew Mr. Cohen's attention. It was the re-emergence of Mr. Kirman himself, an Israeli who had jumped bail in Suffolk County 10 years earlier, after he was charged with selling three ounces of cocaine to an undercover police officer in a Huntington clam bar. Although Suffolk officials knew he had fled to Israel, his trail, they said, had gone cold long ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aristide and the Haitian Military Expected to Open Talks Sunday
nytimes_articles.abstract: Talks between Haiti's exiled President and the army leaders who overthrew him are to begin Sunday at the United Nations, diplomats involved in the negotiations said today, one day after the planned meeting appeared to have been derailed by a dispute over its agenda.   If successful, diplomats said, the meeting would set the stage for the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to return to office after 21 months in exile and to spell out conditions for replacing the military leaders who overthrew him. The talks are also expected to determine the mandate for an international police force that the United Nations and the United States have said must be deployed in Haiti to insure a peaceful transition.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Pop; Haggard, Down Home In Manhattan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Country-music icons are wary about New York City. It's unfamiliar turf, where audiences are smaller but expectations are higher, since country shows are comparatively rare here. The standard 60-minute set always seems too short. Merle Haggard, the latest down-home icon to perform at the 800-seat Tramps, received a hero's welcome from a rowdy, sold-out early-show audience on Wednesday night. But fans shouted so many requests, between and sometimes during songs, that Mr. Haggard looked perturbed, his timing thrown off.   Timing is a good part of Mr. Haggard's music. He sings in a stone-faced deadpan, his mouth barely moving. Dignity, pain and a sense of loss come through his singing in subtleties: a stretched syllable, a suddenly broadened vibrato, a dip to a deep baritone note, a bluesy downward slide. In "Mama Tried," Mr. Haggard's classic song about turning "21 in prison doing life without parole," he sang as if still humbled by remorse over his sins.

nytimes_articles.headline: Time to Eat So Don't Mind Holyfield, He'll Just Pick
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wearing sneakers, sweat pants and a T-shirt, Evander Holyfield weighed in today for his comeback fight Saturday at 218 pounds, the heaviest of his career.   Even with his weighty outfit -- he said he was cold because of a walk on the boardwalk -- Holyfield still was 10 pounds lighter than his opponent, Alex Stewart. But the former heavyweight champion claimed: "It doesn't really make a difference. It's my ability, not my weight. My condition is great."

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. MEMO REVEALS DISPUTE ON BOSNIA
nytimes_articles.abstract: A top State Department human rights official has privately challenged Secretary of State Warren Christopher's public assertions that all three sides share responsibility for atrocities in Bosnia.   In recent testimony to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mr. Christopher asserted that Muslims, Serbs and Croats were all to blame for attacks on civilians.

nytimes_articles.headline: On U.S Health Reform: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The American physician, after obtaining his bachelor's degree, spends an additional eight years, on the average, undergoing medical education and internship. American medical technology leads the world in virtually all kinds of medical science. The world

nytimes_articles.headline: Tokyo Party Still Hunts Business Cash
nytimes_articles.abstract: Faced with the most bitterly contested national elections in four decades, the rapidly unraveling Liberal Democratic Party has apparently begun turning to banks and the business community for financing, even though polls show that the Japanese are fed up with the influence of money in politics.   The governing party's tactics have created a quandary for big corporations and banks over whether to continue to finance a party that has always put their interests and patronage ahead of consumer interests.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nurse to Be AIDS Czar   The President chose a former Washington State health official to be the Federal AIDS coordinator. Page A17.  New Jersey Bests New York    A commission voted to expand McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey by closing Plattsburgh Air Force Base in New York. Page A12. Wilder vs. Robb, Again    Reviving a Virginia feud, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder will challenge Senator Charles Robb for the Democratic Senate nomination. Page A12.  Atom-Smasher Voted Down    The House voted to kill an $11 billion science project in Texas, the Superconducting Supercollider, and proponents said they were pessimistic that the Senate could save it. Page A18.

nytimes_articles.headline: Vanbiesbrouck First Pick, May Haunt Rangers
nytimes_articles.abstract: John Vanbiesbrouck, a first-string goalie who played his first game with the Rangers in 1981, was the first player chosen in the National Hockey League's expansion draft today. His selection was a coup for the Florida Panthers and a twofold blow to the Rangers, who traded him to Vancouver four days ago. Now they not only have hardly anything to show for him, but they also face the nightmare of having him as a divisional opponent.   Vanbiesbrouck was the biggest name among 48 players claimed by the league's two newest franchises, the Panthers and the Anaheim Mighty Ducks. Another was Glenn Healy, the goalie who led the Islanders to the third round of the playoffs. Healy was chosen by the Ducks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Visser Fractures Hip While Jogging
nytimes_articles.abstract: LESLEY VISSER, the CBS Sports reporter, fractured and dislocated a hip Wednesday while jogging in Central Park. She underwent surgery and was listed in stable condition at a New York hospital, where she will remain for several days. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: On Abortion, Judge Ginsburg Backs Democracy; Conscience Protection
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Abortion and the Health Care Package" (editorial, June 12) states: "Of course the proposed new package should include abortion coverage. That's only fair. And it should include a 'conscience clause' that would excuse doctors and hospitals with profound objections to abortion from having to perform them. That would reduce opposition to including abortion. And it's only fair, too. Just as no woman should be forced to continue a pregnancy, no physician should be forced to terminate one. Both are answering to their own consciences."

nytimes_articles.headline: Inquiry Will Check Air Quality on Airplanes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena today ordered a preliminary inquiry into the air quality of airplane cabins.    Airlines in the United States have been circulating less fresh air into the cabins of many newer airplanes to cut costs. As a result, flight attendants and passengers have complained of headaches, nausea and other health problems, especially after long flights.

nytimes_articles.headline: Diner's Journal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Musical Chairs and Table   Pino Luongo is busy reshuffling the deck in his restaurant empire. The tenure of Marta Pulini as chef has just ended at Le Madri, 168 West 18th Street, and Gianni Scappin, who comes from the Venice region with a long resume, has replaced her.   Ms. Pulini has been named executive chef of the new uptown Barneys at Madison Avenue and 61st Street by Mr. Luongo, who has the food-management contract for the store. When it opens in the fall, the store will have Mad 61, a food complex on the lower level with an espresso bar, a wine bar, a retail food shop, a catering service, a cafe and a 100-seat restaurant. Mr. Luongo said he would like the restaurant to offer "Manhattan cuisine," an American-French-Italian fusion. The second floor will have the Chelsea Cafe, emphasizing salads, and on the ninth floor there will be a 50-seat American restaurant with a buffet.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Electronic House-Hunting;
New Jersey Realtor Group and E.D.S. Plan Data Bank
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The residential real estate industry in New Jersey, as in the rest of the Northeast, has been slow to enter the age of high technology. That may soon change with a partnership being molded by the New Jersey Association of Realtors and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation.

They are developing a software network called R.I.S., or Realtor Information Services, aimed at helping consumers to search for homes and helping brokers to close deals, said Carl R. DeMusz, the association's first vice president and the chairman of the task force structuring the partnership.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Abelardo Morell   National Arts Club  15 Gramercy Park South  Through Wednesday    The quirks of the photographic process itself are the subject of many of Abelardo Morell's black-and-white images. Mr. Morell often depicts commonplace objects from unusual angles or framed in surprising ways. Two eggs in a pan of water, ready to be boiled, look like ghostly ovals when seen in closeup; the mouth of an open paper bag, photographed from directly overhead, becomes an irregular black maw.

nytimes_articles.headline: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Investigation; As Plot Built, Agents Watched and Waited
nytimes_articles.abstract: As late as Wednesday night, members of an antiterrorist task force had trouble believing what they were seeing and hearing. Even though, months before, bombers had blown a hole under the World Trade Center, another bombing plot was quickly taking form -- right under the eyes of investigators.   Video cameras and tape recorders hidden in a Queens garage were transmitting the pictures and sounds of conspirators mixing a "witches' brew" of diesel fuel and fertilizer -- ingredients, authorities said, for bombs to blow up the United Nations, the Federal building in Manhattan, Hudson River tunnels and public officials. "Can you believe it?" one official said law-enforcement agents were asking one another. "They're going to go through with it." Eased by Informer    But moments later, their entry apparently eased by an informer in the group, the agents slipped into the garage and, before the targets were aware of the interlopers, slapped handcuffs on them and hauled them away under arrest.

nytimes_articles.headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Burton, undersecretary for the Middle East at the British Foreign Office, is reading Rebecca West's "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon." . "It's a very long and absorbing tale of a journey through Yugoslavia in the '30s, and it's the best

nytimes_articles.headline: Los Angeles Bans All Restaurant Smoking
nytimes_articles.abstract: Beginning a month from today, Angelenos who want to smoke while eating out will have to drive to Beverly Hills or Burbank. In one of his final official acts as Mayor of Los Angeles after 20 years, Tom Bradley today signed a bill making the city the largest in the country to ban smoking altogether in restaurants.   The action came less than a day after the 15-member City Council voted to extend the ban, which already applies to theaters, grocery stores, public buildings and elevators, to the city's 7,000 restaurants.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An obituary headline on Wednesday about Anthony E. Fahnestock misstated his occupation. As noted in the article, he was an investment manager.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Stage, and Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Indefatigable Abbott    Bracing birthday news from George Abbott, the writer, director and producer who celebrates his 106th birthday today: "Damn Yankees," the musical he directed and co-wrote, will be coming to Broadway in March. Bebe Neuwirth will be Lola (as in whatever the lady wants, she gets), and Victor Garber will play the Devil (as in, sell your soul to). Jack O'Brien is the director, and Rob Marshall of the "Kiss of the Spider Woman" team is the leading contender for choreographer.   "The show's as relevant as it ever was, but I've done some reworking," said Mr. Abbott, who brought "Damn Yankees" to Broadway in 1955. The Faustian tale (of a Washington baseball fan who sells his soul to the devil so his team can whip the New York Yankees) won the Tony Award.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The subjects were actually mixing the witches' brew. We entered so fast some of the subjects didn't know we were in the bomb factory until they were in handcuffs." -- JAMES M. FOX, who heads the F.B.I.' New York office.  [ A1:6. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Cruguet Gets Stiff Sentence: 20 Days
nytimes_articles.abstract: JEAN CRUGUET, who won the Triple Crown of racing in 1977 aboard Seattle Slew, was suspended for 20 days yesterday by the stewards at Belmont Park for rough riding. The New York Racing Association stewards said that it was the longest suspension they had imposed in 22 years. Cruguet, now 54 years old, was punished for his ride in the third race last Monday when he finished third aboard Tara's Trumpet. During some jostling down the homestretch, his horse bumped Onda Flora, who finished in front of him in second place. Cruguet lodged a claim of foul against JORGE CHAVEZ, the rider on Onda Flora. But the claim was not allowed, and Cruguet instead was suspended from today through July 14.

nytimes_articles.headline: Amelia Earhart Doesn't Go Uncelebrated; Military Women
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   No, there are not enough women represented in statuary in the United States (Op-Ed, June 14), but we want to alert readers about a big step in the right direction.

nytimes_articles.headline: Last Chance
nytimes_articles.abstract: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend    "WILD MEN," Westside Theater, 407 West 43d Street, Clinton. A comedy with music about five men on a weekend retreat in the woods. Through Sunday. Performances: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 7 and 10 P.M.; Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $35. Information: (212) 307-4100. "DOWN THE ROAD," Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea. A drama by Lee Blessing about criminals who become tabloid celebrities. Through Sunday. Performances: Today and Sunday at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 7 and 10 P.M. Tickets: $25. Information: (212) 645-1242. "THE NIGHT LARRY KRAMER KISSED ME," Perry Street Theater, 31 Perry Street, West Village. A one-man show by David Drake about contemporary American gay culture. Through Sunday. Performances: Today and tomorrow at 7 and 10 P.M.; Sunday at 7 P.M. Tickets: $30 and $32.50. Information: (212) 564-8038. "WRONG TURN AT LUNGFISH," Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. A comedy-drama by Garry Marshall and Lowell Ganz about a cranky college professor and a young streetwise couple. Through Sunday. Hours: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $35 to $39.50. Information: (212) 580-1313. "FALSETTOS," Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, Clinton. A musical about a contemporary New York family. Through Sunday. Performances: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $47.50 to $60. Information: (212) 239-6200. "HELLO MUDDAH, HELLO FADDUH," Circle in the Square Downtown, 159 Bleecker Street, East Village. A comedy featuring the musical parodies of Allan Sherman. Through Sunday. Performances: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 2 and 5:30 P.M. Tickets: $35. Information: (212) 254-6330.

nytimes_articles.headline: Security Was Stepped Up At Two Tunnels and Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey tightened its guard over the George Washington Bridge and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels this week after investigators warned it that those structures had been targeted for bombing by the suspects arrested yesterday.   But an official at the United Nations declared that the international agency had not been alerted before the arrests. The Federal Bureau of Investigation did not return calls about a possible discrepancy in alerting officials from the two organizations, thought to be the principal targets of what the authorities have termed a conspiracy.

nytimes_articles.headline: There's No Safety About Nuclear Tests
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 16 front-page report that Democratic lawmakers will oppose any plan to resume nuclear testing is encouraging. If the United States resumes testing, so too will France, Britain, Russia and China. This will no doubt encourage other countries to join the nuclear arms race, which will damage the security of the United States and the entire world.

nytimes_articles.headline: Schiller Theater To Close in Berlin
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Berlin Senate has announced a number of cultural austerity measures of which the most radical is the closing of the Schiller Theater, one of the leading German-language theaters in Europe and for years West Berlin's principal state-subsidized theater.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Jersey Base Is Backed at New York's Expense
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a decision that helps New Jersey at New York's expense, a Presidential commission today rejected a Pentagon recommendation and voted to create a large East Coast troop-staging base at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey and to close Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York.   Defense Secretary Les Aspin had recommended shrinking McGuire and Griffiss Air Force in Rome, N.Y., and moving many of their missions to Plattsburgh, making it the Air Force's main transportation hub for cargo, soldiers and refueling planes on the East Coast.

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 685593 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Entering Han Bat, a trim little restaurant in the heart of the garment district, is like entering another country. The newspaper sold in the vestibule is The Korea Times. The lunchtime crowd that fills the 100 or so seats is made up mostly of Korean workers and business executives. The air is heavy with the pungent aroma of kim chee, other pickled vegetables and seafood.   Korean restaurants are no longer uncommon in this part of midtown. But Han Bat is unusual because it specializes in the country dishes of southern Korea, like sul long tang, a long-simmered milky beef soup, rather than the table-top barbecuing associated with Korean cooking.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Sarajevo, Silence Turns to Despair
nytimes_articles.abstract: While the Serbian guns that have blasted this city for more than a year have quieted, news reports about a peace plan that would partition Bosnia and Herzegovina have plunged many here into despair.   "Bosnia's partition is only a matter of days away," said Mustafa Spahic, a Muslim cleric, referring to the proposal by the Serbian and Croatian presidents, Slobodan Milosevic and Franjo Tudjman, to divide this country into Serbian, Croatian and Muslim territories.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; When Sam Met Annie, Or When Two Meet Cute
nytimes_articles.abstract: Seattle widower and Baltimore newswoman. Cannily concocted love story, impossible to resist.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fernandez Haunts 2 Teams
nytimes_articles.abstract: Buck Showalter did not want John Olerud hitting with runners in scoring position. Who could blame the Yankee manager? Olerud is merely hitting .405. So twice tonight Showalter had Olerud walked intentionally in order to face Tony Fernandez. And in those situations, Fernandez hit 1.000 tonight.   Fernandez ruined Showalter's strategy by slapping run-scoring singles each time, fetching home a run in the third inning and another run in the fifth. He also smacked a triple.

nytimes_articles.headline: Albany's Environmental Blinders
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just over a century ago, the New York State Legislature, mindful of generations yet unborn, created a treasure: the Adirondack State Park. There is no comparable vision among today's lawmakers, who have trouble seeing beyond the end of the day. Albany's habit of leaving important business until the last minute threatens a noble effort to protect the Adirondacks and may postpone action on two other important environmental issues.    One is to bring New York into compliance with the 1990 Federal Clean Air Act, which obliges states to impose stricter air quality controls on cars and factories. Failure to act could cost the state $800 million a year in Federal highway aid, and Washington is losing patience with Albany's sloth.

nytimes_articles.headline: Step Right Up! Take a Chance!; Players Face Long Odds in Atlantic City Boardwalk Games
nytimes_articles.abstract: Standing in the long shadow of the onion domes, purple turrets and epic staircases of the Trump Taj Mahal casino, the colossal gambling emporium that blocks the late afternoon sunlight on the boardwalk, Bill Ustick is not one to make comparisons.   Donald J. Trump's casino rakes in millions of dollars in bets, while Mr. Ustick presides over the dollar-a-game ring-toss under a canvas canopy on the Steel Pier, just a long roll of the dice from the Taj Mahal's gaudy entrance.   But strip away the trappings and move the bottom-line decimal point a few places and you have two concessionaires who invite the public to step right up, put their money down and try their luck.

nytimes_articles.headline: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Widen Trial Rules on Mental Competence
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that once a criminal defendant is found fit to stand trial under the longtime test of mental competency, he is also competent to dismiss his lawyer and plead guilty to a crime as serious as capital murder.   The 7-to-2 decision overturned a lower court's ruling that because a guilty plea or a waiver of legal counsel "requires a higher level of mental functioning" than standing trial with a lawyer's assistance, the Constitution requires a heightened standard of competency for those actions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ousted Speaker In Albany Wins Case on Appeal
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Federal appeals panel yesterday unanimously overturned the fraud conviction of former Assembly Speaker Mel Miller of Brooklyn, agreeing that a tangled real-estate deal in which he and his former law partner netted $200,000 did not constitute a crime.   Mr. Miller, who as Speaker was the second most powerful Democrat in the state, was stripped of his position but spared a prison term after his conviction in 1991. The conviction effectively ended the political career of a man who for years had cast a dominating, and often domineering, presence over New York State politics.

nytimes_articles.headline: : Talking Business?Watch Your Language
nytimes_articles.abstract: RALPH Waldo Emerson's counsel 150 years ago that "No man should travel until he has learned the language of the country he visits" is reflected in the current boom in language learning for business travelers. Berlitz, Europe's largest school, is

nytimes_articles.headline: Connally's Wounds Held No Secrets
nytimes_articles.abstract:
While the family of John B. Connally, the former Texas governor, buried him, conspiracy theorists advanced specious claims that tiny bullet fragments in his right wrist would prove there was a second gun -- thus a second assassin -- in the slaying of President John F. Kennedy.

In Mr. Connally's wrist were fragments of the bullet that had first passed through Kennedy's neck and then had entered Mr. Connally's back, exited his chest, passed through his right wrist and stopped in his left thigh, when Kennedy was slain in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.

nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurants
nytimes_articles.abstract: The charms of the neighborhood restaurant are well known, or at least well imagined. The warm welcome, the cadre of familiar faces, the table that is always available, the waiter who anticipates every need, the feeling of belonging. There's only one thing missing from this fantasy: the food.   There's a reason. Most neighborhood restaurants are more clubhouse than dining room, with food that is more earnest than surprising. The point of a neighborhood restaurant is its proximity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hans Lehfeldt, 93, Doctor and Leader In Family Planning
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Hans M. Lehfeldt, a New York gynecologist who was one of the earliest proponents and practitioners of family planning, died last Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.   He suffered a long illness, his family said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Panel Wages First Skirmish on Abortion
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anti-abortion forces won the year's first legislative skirmish over Federal financing of abortions today, but they won on a position they would have considered a major defeat only a year ago.   The House Appropriations Committee voted to allow the Government to pay for abortions for poor women in cases of rape, incest and a threat to the life of the pregnant woman. It soundly defeated an attempt to broaden the terms to include a threat to the health of the mother; that vote was 27 to 18.

nytimes_articles.headline: Some European Restaurants Thrive in Crisis
nytimes_articles.abstract: The expense account may be slashed, and the bank may be calling in the mortgage, but if the thriving business at many European restaurants is any indication, food lovers are not exactly sitting home and crying in their beers. .In England, France, and G

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; The Pain and Joy in Jimmy Scott's Voice
nytimes_articles.abstract: Intense pain and great joy are indistinguishable in the voice of Jimmy Scott. Yet the paradox would mean little were it not for the thoughtfulness behind his singing. At the World Financial Center Winter Garden on Wednesday night, Mr. Scott treated a succession of ballads and uptempo tunes to the discursive style that connoisseurs, if not the general public, have admired for many years. The concert was part of the JVC Jazz Festival.   The songs ranged from "All the Way" to "All of Me" with some Gershwin in between. The melodies themselves rarely escape Mr. Scott's lips. He sings about them. Interpretation becomes annotation, gloss, a series of footnotes to the tune in question. Implication and allusion is all in this mysterious style. Mr. Scott has little patience with the obvious.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Not Vital   Baron/Boisante Editions  50 West 57th Street  Manhattan  Through July 16    Not Vital, a Swiss artist who emerged in the recent heyday of the East Village, is an idiosyncratic sculptor with a great feeling for materials and a certain attraction to the absurd, and his work is getting better. The centerpiece of his charming show is a large and rather wonderful sculpture, a white plaster cylinder five feet tall that flares gently outward and upward. Inside, a little lamblike creature, also made of white plaster, stares up at the viewer, its face a mixture of animal and human, vulnerability and curiosity. In their snowy whiteness, animal and container almost blend, creating an apparitional effect and the sense that the animal is more spirit than flesh, a stand-in for the human soul and perhaps a reflection of the viewer.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cuomo Criticizes Panel's Proposal To Close or Scale Back 2 Bases
nytimes_articles.abstract: Calling a Presidential commission's recommendations to close one Air Force base in New York State and partially dismantle a second "not rational," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would ask President Clinton to reject the plan and keep both bases open.   Mr. Cuomo said the closing of Plattsburgh Air Force Base and cutbacks at Griffiss Air Force Base would be "devastating" to the state's economy, costing as many as 8,000 jobs and more than $400 million in revenues.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the financial default of the owner of the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club misstated estimated values in some editions for the former owner's six country club properties now held by the Resolution Trust Corporation. The figures represented hundreds of millions of dollars, not millions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about design versus the environment misidentified the exhibition at which the lithograph "Highways of the Future" is being shown. It is "Chicago Architecture and Design 1923-1993: Reconfiguration of an American Metropolis," at the Art Institute of Chicago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lendl:Not Grand but Still Farewell
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ivan Lendl was manipulating the young Frenchman, turning him around and backward and forward with just a racket and a ball, which is really quite a trick. At that point Thursday, he had many once more imagining the unimaginable. ."How would he rea

nytimes_articles.headline: The West Must Decide What It Intends for Russia
nytimes_articles.abstract: This is the second of two articles.The West's interest in not letting Russia revert to totalitarianism is evident. The direction Russia takes will decisively influence the geopolitical future of much of the world. Without significant assistance, the cou

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Permits Student-Led Prayer at Graduation
nytimes_articles.abstract: One year to the day after the United States Supreme Court banned school-instituted prayer at public-school graduations, a Federal District judge today refused to block a student-led prayer at graduation exercises at Highland High School in Blackwood.   The American Civil Liberties Union sought an injunction on behalf of Edward Ross, a senior who had objected to having a prayer at the graduation next Monday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Homosexuals' Worth : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Witches and Homosexuals" (Letter, June 3): .Well done, Leslie Schenk! Your letter reminds us of facts about homosexuals that should be obvious to all. They are talented, reliable, tolerant and enthusiastic. In my experience in the

nytimes_articles.headline: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Scene; Newcomers Mistaken For Police
nytimes_articles.abstract: For almost two months, Jose Verez watched the mysterious group of men and women come and go from the graffiti-covered garage near the corner of 139th Street and 90th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. They arrived at all times of the day and night. They unloaded boxes and bags from unmarked vans. Some of them carried guns tucked in their waistbands.   Like many of his neighbors, Mr. Verez concluded that the newcomers who rarely said hello must be the police or narcotics officers who were keeping tabs on drug traffic in the area. "I thought, 'Oh, they're Federal agents, so we'll be safe,' " he said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Caramoor Opening
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Caramoor Festival opens this weekend with concerts tomorrow and Sunday on the festival grounds in Katonah, N.Y. Tomorrow's concert, at 8:30 P.M., features Julius Rudel conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke's in an all-Beethoven program, including the "Creatures of Prometheus" Overture, Symphony No. 3 ("Eroica") and the Third Piano Concerto, with Misha Dichter as guest soloist. On Sunday at 5:30 P.M., Mr. Dichter, joined by Cipa Dichter, will give a two-piano recital featuring works of Brahms, Milhaud and Ravel, including Brahms's rarely performed transcription of his Fourth Symphony. This concert celebrates the 20th anniversary of the Dichters' first appearance as a piano duo. Tickets are $10 to $37.50 for tomorrow's performance and $22.50 for Sunday. Information: (914) 232-1252.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Gap Narrows in Talks on Gay Ban, but Can It Be Bridged?
nytimes_articles.abstract: After months of negotiations, the Clinton Administration, Congress and homosexual rights groups have narrowed their differences over homosexuals' service in the military.    Nevertheless, officials say, two major hurdles remain: defining precisely the extent to which homosexuals in uniform may speak about their sexual orientation, and whether to declare homosexuality incompatible with military service.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Dennis, Mr. Wilson, Slow Burns And Cats
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prankish little boy with cowlick. Bland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Thailand vs. the Smugglers : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding the report "Amid Chaos in Cambodia, Raiders Carry Off Temple Treasures" (May 19): .Thailand is also concerned about illicit trafficking of world cultural objects. We are deeply disturbed at the implication of Thailand's lack of resp

nytimes_articles.headline: Demagoguery on Taxes
nytimes_articles.abstract: The muddle-headed spirit of Ronald Reagan stalks Washington this week. Mr. Reagan promised Americans they could maintain their society without taxing themselves to do it. The theory went like this: Limit revenues, and spending will come down.   But under Presidents Reagan and Bush, spending went up, especially for defense. The limits on revenue didn't stop that; the country just went into the red to pay for it. Meanwhile the underclass grew, social divisions sharpened and attitudes toward suffering took on a Dickensian hardness.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Another real estate executive, JERRY I. SPEYER, president of Tishman Speyer Properties, has been elected chairman of the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The partnership is an umbrella group that includes the Chamber of Commerce.   He succeeds Preston Robert Tisch, president and co-chief executive officer of the Loews Corporation. David Rockefeller founded the partnership in 1979 and was chairman of both groups from 1980 to 1988.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Jazz Festival; Bird Lives! And So Does Monk!
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charlie Parker and Thelonious Monk didn't write easy music. Their jagged melodies and extended harmonies separated adepts from also-rans, and gave those adepts a new vocabulary of emotion and technical display. "Aspects of Monk" and "Bird Lives," the two halves of the JVC Jazz Festival concert on Tuesday night at Town Hall, gathered experts for a jam session on each composer; Parker was better served than Monk.   "Bird Lives" featured Red Rodney (who worked with Parker's quintet) on fluegelhorn, alongside Charles McPherson on alto saxophone and Barry Harris on piano. Two younger alto saxophonists, Greg Abate and Jesse Davis, also sat in, all backed by Bob Cranshaw on bass, Mickey Roker on drums and, for a few tunes, Walter Bishop Jr. on piano.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943: Dying for Centuries : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND - [By John Steinbeck. From our New York edition:] A small United Service Organization unit is aboard this troopship, girls and men who are going out to entertain troops wherever they may be sent. These are not the big names who go out

nytimes_articles.headline: Virginia Voters to Referee Feud of Robb and Wilder
nytimes_articles.abstract: Taking one of the nation's nastiest political feuds to the voters, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia announced today that he would oppose Senator Charles S. Robb for the Democratic Senate nomination next year.   Mr. Wilder's candidacy is certain to add fuel to a long-running, highly public battle between the state's two leading Democrats and draw further attention to a Senate race in which Oliver L. North, who became a national figure virtually overnight as a result of the Iran-contra affair, is expected to seek the Republican nomination.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. SETS PENALTY FOR RUSSIAN FIRMS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States has imposed sanctions on Russian companies for selling missile technology in violation of international export controls, Clinton Administration officials said today.    But the sanctions have been waived until mid-July while Washington and Moscow make a last-ditch effort to resolve their differences.

nytimes_articles.headline: Taking a Cue From Ford : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Europe's Auto Industry Tries to Turn a Corner" (June 2): .Europe's auto executives have obviously never heard how Henry Ford raised his workers' salaries so they could buy Ford cars. These days the executives raise their own salari

nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Focusing Like a Laser on Medical Costs" (Opinion, May 12):I also underwent medical treatment to avert retinal detachment, not in France but in Britain, where for 24 years I have been registered with the National Health Service, and

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Carol Haussamen, den mother, confidante and fund-raiser for hundreds of Democratic candidates over the last quarter of a century, was enamored of the garden behind the building she owned and lived in at 40 Central Park South in Manhattan. Mrs. Haussamen's parents, L. Victor and Beatrice Weil, built the apartment house in 1941, and three generations have lived there.    As Mrs. Haussamen's health declined, so did the attention she could pay to the garden. She died of cancer of the esophagus last November at the age of 71.

nytimes_articles.headline: Endeavour Grabs Satellite Easily But Bringing It Home Is Tougher
nytimes_articles.abstract: The space shuttle Endeavour dashed through the darkness today to snatch a valuable European scientific satellite from its orbital perch for a scheduled trip back to Earth, but two loose antennas delayed the completion of the retrieval.   Space agency officials said that the capture of the big satellite had gone flawlessly but that the help of space-walking astronauts would be needed to tuck it securely away in the shuttle's cargo bay for the trip home.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Abortion, Judge Ginsburg Backs Democracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Kathleen Quinn's criticism of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg's position on Roe v. Wade in "Treat Judge Ginsburg Like a Man" (Op-Ed, June 20) exemplifies the distortions that come from arguments by anecdote. Ms. Quinn disputes the belief of the Supreme Court nominee that liberalizing forces were at work in state legislatures when the high court's sweeping abortion decision abruptly mooted these democratic processes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Results Plus
nytimes_articles.abstract: GOLF  2 Share Seniors Lead  Jim Albus and Bob Charles each shot six-under-par 66's to share the first-round lead in the Senior Players Championship at the sun-drenched TPC of Michigan yesterday in Dearborn, Mich. They were one stroke ahead of Jack Nicklaus, who designed the 6,876-yard course, and Jim Colbert. The top of the leader board was a familiar spot for Albus, who stunned the golf world by winning this tournament in 1991 while still working as a club pro at Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I. (AP) Stadler and Maltbie Fire 65's: Craig Stadler and Roger Maltbie came within a shot of the course record as they shot five-under-par 65's to share the first-round lead in the Canon Greater Hartford Open in Cromwell, Conn. John Huston, Keith Clearwater and Dan Forsman are a shot back and nine players, including Nick Price and Corey Pavin, were at three under. A day after only six players broke par on the TPC at River Highlands course during a celebrity pro-am because of wind gusting to 25 miles an hour. (AP) YACHT RACING  New Winners in Day 4  Shifting winds off the Rhode Island coast yesterday stirred up a new set of winners in the fourth day of Block Island Race Week. Merrythought, the 62-foot sloop owned by Jack King of Annapolis, Md., edged the 50-foot Infinity out of the overall big-boat lead. Sailing aboard Merrythought was Gary Jobson, an America's Cup veteran. Both boats were designed by Bruce Farr of Annapolis, but Merrythought is 10 years older. Racing for the first time this month, Infinity, owned by John Thomson, of Port Washington, L.I., has been the favorite to win its class at Block Island. In another upset, Blue Yankee, a 43-foot sloop owned by Robert Towse, of Stamford, Conn., took over the lead in Class 2 from the 43-foot Barrister III. Eddie-Warden Owen, the top-ranked match-racer from England, sailed on Blue Yankee. BOXING  Knockout for Snipes  Renaldo Snipes, a 36-year-old former heavyweight contender on the comeback trail, made his fourth payday in the last three years pay off last night at the Paramount, where Madison Square Boxing staged its next-to-last program. The 215-pound Snipes raised his career record to 39-7-1 by scoring his 22d knockout, stopping Eddy Curry, a 193-pound cruiserweight, at 2 minutes 16 seconds of the third round. Snipes, a popular local fighter out of Yonkers, is hoping to be invited back to the last Garden-promoted card, scheduled for July 8. He floored Larry Holmes in his only title shot, a World Boxing Council challenge in 1981. But a controversial long count allowed the champion to get up, and then Holmes knocked out Snipes in the 11th round. In last night's featured bout, Lamar Parks, ranked among middlweight contenders by the W.B.C., came back from a first-round knockdown to win a unanimous decision over Danny Garcia of San Juan, P.R. Vasquez Keeps Title: Wilfredo Vasquez of Puerto Rico retained his World Boxing Association super-bantamweight title last night by knocking out Thierry Jacob of France 45 seconds into the 10th round in Bordeaux, France. (AP)
