nytimes_articles.abstract: Calling all buckaroos! It doesn't matter if you live in a city of 6 million people, you, too, can be a cowboy for a day (or more) and "Ride with the Rock Creek Gang on the 1800s Period Cattle Drive....Live the legendary COWBOY LIFE, riding herd all d

nytimes_articles.headline: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Overview; 8 SEIZED AS SUSPECTS IN PLOT TO BOMB NEW YORK TARGETS AND KILL POLITICAL FIGURES
nytimes_articles.abstract: A suspected terrorist organization that had planned a horrific campaign of bombing and political assassination in New York City this summer was smashed early yesterday with the arrest of eight men, all said to be Muslim extremists, at raids in Queens, Brooklyn, Yonkers and Jersey City, Federal authorities said.   After nearly five months of surveillance by an Arabic-speaking confidential informer -- apparently an insider who tape-recorded the group's plots -- heavily armed Federal and city law-enforcement officials swooped down before dawn on a suspected bomb factory and other locations even as some of the men mixed vats of chemicals for bomb strikes that were apparently to begin in a few days. 'Mixing the Witches' Brew'    "The subjects were actually mixing the witches' brew," James M. Fox, the head of the F.B.I.'s New York office, said of five men caught, he said, as they stirred 55-gallon drums of explosive nitrates and diesel fuel in a hideout in Jamaica, Queens. "We entered so fast some of the subjects didn't know we were in the bomb factory until they were in handcuffs."

nytimes_articles.headline: KURDISH MILITANTS RAID TURKISH SITES IN EUROPEAN CITIES
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Kurdish rebels mounted a wave of coordinated assaults on Turkish diplomatic missions and businesses across Europe today, seizing hostages and battling the police in a violent attempt to call attention to their nine-year struggle to gain independence from Turkey. 

Militants, believed to be from the Marxist-oriented Kurdish Workers Party, stormed the Turkish consulates in Munich and Marseilles, France, and attacked Turkish diplomatic missions, airline offices and banks in more than a dozen German cities and in Switzerland, Sweden and Denmark, police officials said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; The Loss of a Child Who's Still Present
nytimes_articles.abstract: Widow tries to reach autistic daughter. Total murk.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ex-Washington State Official to Get AIDS Post
nytimes_articles.abstract: After being turned down by several other candidates, President Clinton will name Kristine Gebbie, a nurse who was the top health official in the State of Washington, to become the country's first Federal AIDS coordinator, White House officials say.    The officials said Mr. Clinton is also expected to nominate Harold Varmus, a Nobel Prize-winning molecular biologist from the University of California, to take over the National Institutes of Health.

nytimes_articles.headline: At The New Yorker, They Take Their Fact Checking Seriously
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A footnote on the Janet Malcolm-Jeffrey Masson libel case:    That Janet Malcolm rolled scenes together does not mean that the checking department at The New Yorker is a sham.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; The Players Turn Backs On Caution
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN times of trouble, one defiant act can change the world. In a Goya painting, one Spanish patriot brandishes a fist at Napoleon's executioners, as if urging his countrymen not to lose heart. The optimistic gesture at Wimbledon is to turn a chair sideways, back where it always used to be.   First one chair was shifted 90 degrees, then another. At first, these marching chairs could not be heard on the lush lawns of London SW19, but then most of the players began moving their chairs in a noisy demonstration, turning their backs on the closest strangers in the crowd.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart in some copies yesterday headed "Tracking Down Parents," about child support payments, misstated the amount owed by parents in Nassau County. It is $2.035 million.

nytimes_articles.headline: In a Tokyo Hotel Room, The Swords Came Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the samurai dramas that attract millions of Japanese television viewers, crafty warriors from Japan's feudal past always meet at some out-of-the-way inn, plotting the overthrow of their masters.    The modern reprise came the other night. Masayoshi Takemura and nine colleagues in Parliament slipped into a hotel near the Imperial Palace, took a room with a well-stocked mini-bar and decided that the moment had arrived to ambush the old men who had ruled Japan for 38 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Silence Of the Slam: Lendl Fails
nytimes_articles.abstract: For Ivan Lendl, the haunted Lear of Wimbledon, his 14th attempt to conquer the only tournament to elude his Grand Slam appetite was no charm. It was even more tragic than usual. With the silent grimace that has turned into his trademark here, and has lately seemed to accompany him everywhere, the 33-year-old Lendl today absorbed his worst defeat at Wimbledon since a first-round exit in 1981.   But today's second-round upset on Court 1 came without soliloquy: Lendl was so distraught after his 4-6, 7-5, 6-3, 6-4 loss to Arnaud Boetsch, a 24-year-old, 24th-ranked Parisian, that he marched off the grounds, commandeered a courtesy car, and departed Wimbledon without a word -- for perhaps the last time.

nytimes_articles.headline: HOUSE DEALS BLOW TO SUPERCOLLIDER
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a stinging defeat for high-priced scientific research, the House voted overwhelmingly today to halt construction on the superconducting supercollider, the $11 billion proton-smasher in Texas.   Coming a day after the House voted by a razor-thin margin to continue an even more expensive big-science project, the space station, the defeat of the supercollider provided dramatic evidence of the way budget pressures were forcing lawmakers to choose among projects that in better times might all receive Government funds.

nytimes_articles.headline: Humanitarian Gestures Meet the Human Will
nytimes_articles.abstract: FROM the murky moral jungle of the war in the former Yugoslavia, a 38-year-old Croatian truck driver from Tuzla with an ankle shattered by shrapnel arrived here two months ago at St. Raphael's Hospital with an eager smile and an iron-willed agenda.   His name was Petar Jerkovic (pronounced YER-ko-vich), and he spoke no English, and apparently learned little except "Super!" in his months here. His story, to a great degree, is the story of his wound, how he insisted it be treated, and how he flew home this week determined to rejoin his wife and two daughters at a refugee camp in Germany -- contrary to the wishes of his international escorts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; The Self Stays Strong Amid Shades Of Prejudice
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kathe Sandler's documentary film "A Question of Color" begins with a sequence in which a group of black men and women of varying complexions recite many of the terms, from "high yellow" to "chocolate" to "blue-black," that are used to describe differences in skin tone. From this formal opening, the film plunges bravely into the ticklish subject of color consciousness among blacks.   What it finds is the prevalence of a subtle caste system in which those whose looks come closest to approximating white European standards of attractiveness tend to fare better in American society than those who look more African. It also finds that the tensions generated by this system, which is really an internalized expression of white racism, leave almost everybody feeling insecure. While those who are darker skinned are made to feel less desirable as mates and tend not to do as well economically, light-skinned blacks can find themselves accused of being pretenders to their African heritage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Amelia Earhart Doesn't Go Uncelebrated
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Put More Women on a Pedestal" (Op-Ed, June 14): Perhaps Lynn Sherr and Jurate Kazickas should have looked a little harder for statues of "authentic American heroines."

nytimes_articles.headline: Jefferies Has Finally Grown Up, All the Way to .327
nytimes_articles.abstract: To listen to Gregg Jefferies, he hasn't had much time to study the New York Mets' precipitous plunge in the standings. The St. Louis Cardinals' first baseman is simply glad that he will arrive in New York on Friday as a young man finally at peace with himself.   Far back in the rearview mirror now are three-plus largely unfulfilled seasons with the Mets, ending after the 1991 season when he was traded to Kansas City.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; Test of Leadership
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Soviet-American treaty banning all but underground nuclear tests is nearly 30 years old now, and we tend to take it for granted. We forget that it exists only because a President was courageous enough to lead.   June 1963 was a time of high tension in the cold war. Less than eight months before, we had come to the brink of nuclear war over Soviet deployment of missiles in Cuba. The American political mood was overwhelmingly hawkish.

nytimes_articles.headline: Council Needs Action More Than a Hero
nytimes_articles.abstract: The last action hero terminated himself as chairman of the President's Commission on Physical Fitness and Sports several months ago, and this week he was replaced by two former Olympic athletes, which will make a difference in the shape of our future only if they do what Arnold Schwarzenegger didn't -- translate all that energy and discipline into a national program of healthful, joyful, inexpensive and accessible play.   One hopeful sign was the First Jogger's evident understanding of sports as symbol. At the White House reception for the first National Sports Awards on Sunday, President Clinton, his face dangerously sun-red, declared that the 18 holes of golf he had just played with Arnold Palmer was his best presidential perk so far. Later that night, at Constitution Hall, he looked properly humble as Muhammad Ali asked him for his autograph.

nytimes_articles.headline: Terrorism on Two Continents; In New York, a Catastrophe Averted
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Yorkers are grateful for the story they didn't have to read in their newspapers or experience firsthand. Bomb attacks on the Hudson River tunnels, the United Nations and F.B.I. headquarters . . . assassinations of local and international public figures . . . mayhem, chaos, terror. The city owes thanks to Federal and local antiterrorist units for yesterday's pre-emptive arrests of eight suspects.    Thirteen years of close cooperation between Federal and local antiterrorism units paid off yesterday morning. Using an informant, authorities had patiently tracked these suspects for months as they allegedly discussed targets, carried out reconnaissance and acquired a safe house, vehicles and bomb ingredients. When the agents heard that the suspects had begun to mix diesel fuel and fertilizer in 55-gallon drums and that several were preparing to flee the U.S., they quickly moved in.

nytimes_articles.headline: Subcommittee's Path Runs Into Layers of Complexity
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations will address a number of complex issues Friday when it opens hearings on the management and financial practices of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.   The hearings are the latest in a series examining the operation of Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans around the country. Empire, with more than 8 million policy holders, is the largest of the organizations, which are nonprofit.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918:Retreat in Italy : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ROME - General Diaz today [June 24] issued the following communiqué: During the daytime yesterday we achieved the supreme result of our victory. Pressed against the banks of the Piave, on a strip of ground becoming ever narrower, bombarded ceaselessl

nytimes_articles.headline: Ace Beats Wild Card in Five-Set Poker
nytimes_articles.abstract: Goran Ivanisevic's case of five-set fever continued to plague him tonight at Wimbledon, where the stormy Croat needed to take the ultimate gamble, shut his eyes and hurtle a second-serve ace down the middle of the court to stave off a fifth-set match point against 263d-ranked Chris Bailey, a British wild card who played with the sort of reckless abandon Ivanisevic admires -- in himself.   The savior of a shot came only after Ivanisevic's initial attempt at a second-serve bullet smacked the net and somehow forced itself over into legal territory for the let that allowed him a chance to throw the service dice one more time.

nytimes_articles.headline: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Suspects; Arrested in Yesterday's Raid
nytimes_articles.abstract: SIDDIG IBRAHIM SIDDIG ALI   Mr. Siddig Ali, 32, arrived from the Sudan about seven years ago. The authorities called him the leader of the plot. He lives at 112 Brunswick Avenue in Jersey City.    A member of the al-Salaam Mosque in Jersey City described Mr. Ali as a "religious activist who's outspoken" and who was a leader in helping raise money to pay for the legal fees of the six defendants charged in the World Trade Center bombing and for the defense of El Sayyid Nosair, who was convicted of a gun charge in the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane.

nytimes_articles.headline: Terrorism on Two Continents; In Europe, Kurds Injure Themselves
nytimes_articles.abstract: Despair and anger contributed to the attacks yesterday by Kurdish militants against Turkish embassies and businesses in five European countries. But ignorance and zealotry were also at work in a wave of terrorism that tarnishes the Kurdish cause. The Kurds won no friends by threatening to kill some 20 hostages in Munich unless Chancellor Helmut Kohl ordered Ankara to cease attacking Kurdish villages in southeastern Turkey.    Mr. Kohl held his ground and the hostages were freed. Even so, such acts can hardly help Kurdish causes, including that of the Kurds seeking political asylum in Germany. Worse still is the moral irony: Kurds who attack Turks because they are Turks put themselves on the same level as Germany's racist skinheads who firebomb Turkish guest-workers because of their nationality.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pocklington Ready to Pack. Again.
nytimes_articles.abstract: PETER POCKLINGTON, owner of the Edmonton Oilers, is scheduled to speak with the National Hockey League Board of Governors in Quebec today regarding his renewed threat to move the team, possibly to Hamilton, Ontario.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Rites of Passage Toward Great Unhappiness
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Infinite Plan   By Isabel Allende   Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden   382 pages. HarperCollins. $23.     In her latest novel, "The Infinite Plan," Isabel Allende abandons the hot, politically turbulent Latin American milieu of her earlier fiction for a generic American setting. She also exchanges the strong, beautiful heroines of "The House of the Spirits" and "Eva Luna" for a prideful, strutting male protagonist and trades in the softly accented magical realism of such previous books for a more leaden-footed brand of naturalism. This results in a Bildungsroman-cum-family saga that owes more to Judith Krantz than to Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: JEAN KENNEDY SMITH reported for duty yesterday as the United States Ambassador to Ireland, presenting her credentials to President Mary Robinson in Dublin, The Associated Press reported.    Mrs. Smith noted that it was 30 years ago that she accompanied her brother President John F. Kennedy on a trip to Ireland, their ancestral homeland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; What the Heart Craves, the Body Must Seek
nytimes_articles.abstract: Serial sex, downtown. Misguided, farfetched gay and bisexual ``La Ronde,'' with clunky one-liners.

nytimes_articles.headline: F.C.C. Split May Imperil Post Waiver for Murdoch
nytimes_articles.abstract: A potential division has emerged among the three members of the Federal Communications Commission over whether to grant Rupert Murdoch a waiver that he needs to acquire the bankrupt New York Post.   While the disagreement could be resolved, it casts new doubt on whether Mr. Murdoch will be able to proceed with his plans to permanently regain control of the newspaper he was forced to give up in 1988.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Haim Steinbach   Sonnabend Gallery  420 West Broadway  (near Spring Street)  SoHo  Through July 30    Of the artists dealing with commodity culture in the 1980's, Haim Steinbach and Jeff Koons were by far the most interesting, although they have followed divergent paths in the last few years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yale Professor Is Injured by Blast; Mail Bomb Tied to Terror in 70's
nytimes_articles.abstract: A prominent computer science professor at Yale University was critically injured yesterday by a mail bomb that Federal officials said marked the re-emergence of a mysterious bomber who terrorized campuses and high- technology companies around the country in the 1970's and 80's.   The package exploded shortly after 8 A.M. at the computer science center at Yale in New Haven. The authorities said they believed it had come from the same person who sent a bomb to a professor at the University of California at San Francisco on Tuesday and who has sent 12 other similar packages since 1978. A Group Called 'FC'    Scores of law-enforcement officials have tried for years to track down the bomber, whom they called Unibom, for University Bomber. The authorities have never been able to establish a motive or precise pattern to the bombings, but officials said yesterday that the bomber's distinct signature was clear from the material used to make the bombs. They also made the connection to the earlier incidents from a letter received yesterday by The New York Times.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: EMPIRE IS FAULTED IN INQUIRY   United States Senate investigators have determined that the financial problems of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer, are largely a result of its own mismanagement. A1. A Senate subcommittee will address a number of issues when it opens hearings on Empire. B6.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; Fear of Compassion
nytimes_articles.abstract: At last, the Government of the United States is pulling itself together -- White House, Congress, Supreme Court -- to show how determined and target-minded it can be when it comes to handling a social crisis.    Well, not all social crises -- not things like controlling the gun epidemic that sickens American life, or helping the mentally ill to get the care to take them off the streets, or pushing the war against drugs to the victory in sight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Maradona, in Argentina, Says He's Done
nytimes_articles.abstract: DIEGO MARADONA returned to Argentina yesterday and said he would not play soccer again. Maradona, who returned from Spain following the expiration of his one-season contract with Sevilla in the Spanish first division, said that "after the match with Burgos, I realized it was the end for me." During the June 13 match, Maradona was substituted for by coach and longtime mentor CARLOS BILARDO, whom he insulted while talking to TV interviewers. The striker threw his captain's arm band on the ground and stormed off the field. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Sounds Around Town
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hasil Adkins   Hasil Adkins, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-4064. Hasil Adkins could have crawled out of the muck and slime of rock-and-roll's illegitimate past: his crazy swagger, hoarse holler and ruckus-raising rhythms hark back to a pre-Elvis era when the music was just a raw, rural urge.  Menster Phip and the Phipsters, a ragged bunch of three-chord stompers who eviscerate oldies like "Roll Over Beethoven" and "Mashed Potatoes," are to open the show. Shows are tomorrow at 10 P.M. and Sunday at 9 P.M. Admission is $7. From Monsterland    Monsterland, CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 982-4052. With its classic combination of punk and pop, Monsterland brings out the sweetness in distortion. In songs like "Peanut Butter Karma" and a version of Blondie's "(I'm Always Touched by Your) Presence, Dear," the guitars are layered on thick and cymbals crash calamitously, but the melodies have an airy prettiness. Monsterland may not have invented the formula, but its rushes of guitar noise come close to the essence of melancholia. The show is tonight at 1:30 A.M. Admission is $8. Love and Longing    Chris Stamey and Syd Straw, Fez, under Time Cafe, 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, Greenwich Village. (212) 533-2680. With its narrow stage, red-and-gold curtain backdrop and healthful menu, Fez feels more like a cabaret than a rock club; it's a comfortable, grown-up place to see a singer and songwriter like Chris Stamey. His literate, well-made tunes are little epiphanies that capture moments of love and longing, and although he's not the most emotive performer in the world, his words often betray more than he's letting on. The folk-pop chanteuse Syd Straw floats easily between jazzy standards and tongue-in-cheek readings of AC/ DC hits. Shows are tomorrow night at 9:30 and 11. Admission is $10.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Picasso'  'The Unpublished Graphics'   Jan Krugier Gallery  41 East 57th Street  Manhattan  Through July 26    This show is a gem of the waning art season, reminding us powerfully, if anyone needed to be reminded, of Picasso's restless and dazzling energy. It includes prints made between 1914 and 1961 that Picasso for one reason or another kept and never published, and that eventually ended up in the hands of Marina Picasso, his granddaughter, whose estate is represented by Krugier.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893:Queen's Comédie : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - By command of the Queen a contingent of the Comédie-Française will give a performance at Windsor Castle next week. The pieces selected for that evening are "L'Eté de la St. Martin" and "La Joie Fait Peur." The C

nytimes_articles.headline: THE MOVIE GUIDE : Magnificat
nytimes_articles.abstract: Directed by Pupi Avati. Italy. .Just your average, everyday, lighthearted romp through the fiefdoms, monasteries and dark superstitions of medieval Italy. Judging from the scope and setting, Pupi Avati probably intended this film to be his masterpiece.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Democrats Block Efforts To Alter Clinton's Budget Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Democrats held ranks in the Senate Thursday and early today in the face of solid Republican opposition and defeated all Republican efforts to change a five-year budget package that follows President Clinton's approach in most important respects.   The measure, the subject of one of the most belligerently partisan debates of any major legislation in years, is the most crucial bill of the year to the President.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/City Ballet; Balanchine In Works Gentle And Fierce
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because George Balanchine prized the order and harmony of traditional ballet technique, he is often termed a classicist. But ballets involve more than technique. Many of Balanchine's works are filled with such powerful images of yearning, passion and turmoil that it is possible to argue that he was temperamentally a Romanticist.   He certainly wore his Romantic heart on his sleeve in 1980 when he created "Ballade" and "Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbundlertanze,' " both of which were presented by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night as part of its Balanchine Celebration at the New York State Theater.

nytimes_articles.headline: Attacks Focus the Spotlight On Kurds' Tangled Affairs
nytimes_articles.abstract: The attacks by Kurdish separatists on Turkish installations in Europe today reflected a tactical shift by a Marxist group that has been fighting a little-heeded, but violent, guerrilla war in remote southeastern Turkey for more than nine years.   The assaults in Western Europe propelled the separatist message to a far broader audience. They also evoked the tangles of expediency and ethnic passions that have been molding the destinies of some 20 million Kurds who form minorities in parts of Turkey, Iran, Syria and Iraq, the heart of one of the world's most volatile regions.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Window on Shopping in Tokyo
nytimes_articles.abstract: It may not be the cheapest place to shop, but just looking in this city is a feast for the eyes. Department store merchandise in the West often has all the style of a garage sale. In Japan, the famous depatos on the Ginza (Tokyo's Fifth Avenue) offer ele

wiki_events.headline: Kim Campbell is sworn in as the first female Prime Minister of Canada.

pages.title: Kim Campbell
pages.abstract: Avril Phaedra Douglas "Kim" Campbell is a Canadian politician, diplomat, lawyer, and writer who served as the 19th prime minister of Canada from June 25 to November 4, 1993. Campbell is the first and so far only female prime minister of Canada. Prior to becoming the final Progressive Conservative (PC) prime minister, she was also the first woman to serve as minister of justice in Canadian history and the first woman to become minister of defence in a NATO member state.

pages.title: List of prime ministers of Canada
pages.abstract: The prime minister of Canada is an official who serves as the primary minister of the Crown, chair of the Cabinet, and thus head of government of Canada. Twenty-three people have served as prime ministers. Officially, the prime minister is appointed by the governor general of Canada, but by constitutional convention, the prime minister must have the confidence of the elected House of Commons. Normally, this is the leader of the party caucus with the greatest number of seats in the house. But if that leader lacks the support of the majority, the governor general can appoint another leader who has that support or may dissolve parliament and call a new election. By constitutional convention, a prime minister holds a seat in parliament and, since the early 20th century, this has more specifically meant the House of Commons.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: GOLF  Pavin Grabs a 2-Stroke Lead  Corey Pavin, who lost in a playoff to Billy Ray Brown two years ago, used precise iron shots and ideal morning conditions to shoot a five-under-par 65 yesterday and take a two-stroke lead midway through the Greater Hartford Open in Cromwell, Conn. Wind gusting to 20 miles an hour yesterday afternoon kept later starters from making a strong run at Pavin, who completed 36 holes at 132, eight-under for two rounds over the 6,280-yard Tournament Players Club at River Highlands. Keith Clearwater shot 68 to gain a share of second place at 134 with Mike Springer. The first-round co-leaders, Roger Maltbie and Craig Stadler, had wind problems, each shooting 71 to drop to four-under. Lanny Wadkins failed in an attempt to become the first repeat champion of the Hartford, shooting a 73 for 147 and missing the cut. A two-time Hartford winner, Paul Azinger, was 12-over after a 77. (AP) Thunderstorm Halts Senior Players Championship: Jim Colbert and Rocky Thompson were in the clubhouse at 5-under-par 139 when a thunderstorm halted yesterday's second round of the Senior Players Championship in Dearborn, Mich. Thompson shot a one-under 71 and Colbert matched par at 72. An inch of rain fell in an hour on the TPC of Michigan golf course, and two hours later officials decided they couldn't get the bunkers into playable condition in time to complete the second round. Thirty-nine players, half the field, faced a restart early this morning to complete the second round. When the horn sounded to halt play, first-round co-leader Jim Albus was six-under after 13 holes and Bob Charles, the other first-round leader, was four-under after 12 holes. Jack Nicklaus, who started the day one shot off the lead, was at five-under after nine holes. "I'm looking at a 20-foot putt for par when I go back out to finish the 10th," Nicklaus said. "I'm not real sure I want to handle that at 6:30 in the morning." Brian Henning, a rules official for the senior tour, said second-round play would be completed by 9 A.M. today. Third-round play would begin at 9:30 A.M. (AP) YACHT RACING  Merrythought Wins at Block Island

nytimes_articles.headline: PANEL ON ECOLOGY SHOWING PROGRESS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The commission created to translate the environmental accords of last year's Earth Summit into action wrapped up its first substantive session on an upbeat note today, with tension between rich countries and poor ones uncommonly relaxed and the United States winning praise for leading a new effort to bridge the gap between North and South.   At a high-level ministerial session on Thursday, the United States announced that it was joining with Colombia, the current head of the 129 developing countries calling themselves the Group of 77, in a special effort over the next year to work out a vital issue that has divided the global haves and have-nots: how technology aimed at improving the environment should be transferred to the developing nations.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Images of Horror That Wouldn't Go Away
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN common dread the city came together.   Suddenly, everywhere, a brand-new apocalyptic vision was being shared, one that exposed the vulnerability of this island long reaching for the sky.

nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 15 article questioning the value of the General Education Development diploma, especially relating to New York City, misses or misstates several salient points.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dreamland, N.J.
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's every incumbent politician's dream -- an election-year tax cut. In New Jersey, Republicans in the State Assembly fancied that a cut in the personal income tax this year would put Gov. Jim Florio on the spot and, of course, enhance their own popularity. But the politically astute Governor has pulled a fast one and also lobbied for a tax cut -- not as big as the G.O.P.'s, but still a cut.   A scorecard may help here: Governor Florio, a Democrat, is seeking a second term. But the huge tax increase he pushed through the then-Democratic Legislature three years ago was so unpopular that a year later the Republicans won veto-proof majorities in both houses. Thus chastened, Mr. Florio is unlikely to force another showdown on taxes anytime soon.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Nomads of Albany
nytimes_articles.abstract: Talk about party animals. Night after night, nomadic herds of Albany lobbyists can be seen wandering from one campaign fund-raiser to the next. They keep to a tightly packed itinerary that may include as many as eight different events on some nights when the State Legislature is in town.   It's not the hors d'oeuvres the lobbyists are after, reports Kevin Sack of The Times. Like the crowd on the Congressional fund-raising circuit, the Albany party-hoppers are out to influence legislation. Their nocturnal rounds underscore a recent change for the worse in the already seamy political culture of the New York State Legislature -- and the critical need for reform.

nytimes_articles.headline: 7 Bodies of Asian Immigrants Unidentified After 3 Weeks
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly three weeks after a ship crammed with Chinese immigrants ran aground off Queens, 7 of the 10 bodies of those who perished trying to swim ashore are still unidentified.    Community organizations, trying to help families concerned that a relative may be among the victims, complain that the Immigration and Naturalization Service has been unwilling to release photographs or other vital information needed to identify the bodies and bury them properly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Again Rejects a Limit on Punitive Damages
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court today upheld a $10 million award of punitive damages for a $19,000 injury in a ruling that once again dashed the hopes of critics of the civil justice system who wanted the Court to place a meaningful constitutional limit on punitive damages.   The 6-to-3 ruling made little if any new law and was not supported by a single majority opinion. It was the fifth time in recent years that the Justices did not issue a definitive ruling on punitive damages after suggesting that they were troubled by the issue.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the annulment of the Nigerian presidential election referred incorrectly in some editions to Lagos. It is the former capital; Abuja is the new one.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: Playoffs to determine the United States teams in the 1993 world championships in Chile in September continued here today. In the open final, after 32 deals of a scheduled 128, the Spingold team, including Michael Becker of Tenafly, N.J., led the Vanderbilt team, including Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., by 59 imps.   In semifinal play last night, Spingold won by 5 imps against a team from Chicago, while Vanderbilt coasted to a 42-imp win against the Reisinger team, including David Berkowitz, Larry Cohen and Sam Lev from the New York area. In the playoff between the losers, Chicago led Reisinger by 8.

nytimes_articles.headline: Strawberry's Thinking 1994
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dodgers outfielder Darryl Strawberry, docked a day's pay for showing up late for Thursday's game, arrived four hours early today for tonight's game. On the disabled list with a bad back, he announced he was not talking to reporters for the remainder of the season.   "Nothing to be said," said Strawberry, who lost $19,230 of his $3.5 million annual salary for skipping his rehabilition workout Thursday. "I'm not talking to the press anymore the rest of the year. I'm finished."

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Bluntly Warns Iraq To Yield to Arms Inspectors
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton warned Iraq today that its continuing refusal to allow United Nations inspectors to monitor missile test sites could have "quite serious" consequences, and he said the matter must be resolved soon.   The blunt statement reflected increasing American impatience with the renewed Iraqi intransigence. Despite a similarly strong warning from the United Nations Security Council, Iraq has given no sign that it will back down from its refusal to permit the inspections.

nytimes_articles.headline: Saddam's Other Victims
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In the huge marshes and lakes that cover southern Iraq, Shiite rebels and local tribesmen are fighting a protracted guerrilla war against the forces of Saddam Hussein. Yet, because they are isolated by geography and religion -- they share a faith, Shiism, with the mullahs of Iran -- their plight has received much less international attention than that of the Iraqi Kurds.

To be sure, last August a no-fly zone, patrolled by British, French and U.S. aircraft, was established south of the 32d parallel, covering the marshes and major cities of southern Iraq. But since then the repression of the several hundred thousand inhabitants of the marshes has, if anything, been stepped up.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: It was a scholarly ceremony in Los Angeles on Thursday when GEORGE BURNS was awarded an honorary doctor of humane letters degree from Brandeis University. But the comedian and actor, 97, couldn't resist injecting his own humor into the occasion.    "He said he was going right home to tell his parents because they always wanted a doctor in the family," said Dr. SAMUEL O. THIER, the president of Brandeis, which is in Waltham, Mass. "He pointed out that his father would have been 142 and his mother 119, demonstrating that his father liked younger women."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Pop; Heartfelt Reflection, Splashy Amplification
nytimes_articles.abstract: Can introspection be reborn as spectacle? That's what Peter Gabriel attempts in his current tour, which came to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. Mr. Gabriel has mounted a pop extravaganza with all the trimmings: two stages, a giant video screen, smoke machines, props, choreography. The staging dramatizes not the cheerful come-ons and love songs of Madonna or Paula Abdul, but the private pain and interior struggles of Mr. Gabriel's characters.   With elegiac tunes that are close to hymns and marches, the songs from "Us" (Geffen), Mr. Gabriel's current album, mourn the end of a love affair, trying to find solace and some reason to hope. Such material isn't unprecedented as big-budget pop spectacle; Pink Floyd and the Pet Shop Boys have both staged their own dark ruminations for mass audiences. Like those groups, Mr. Gabriel sets out to create unhurried, dreamlike imagery in the most prosaic of settings, a sports arena.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: You just knew that everybody coming through had the exact same thing on their mind. Every last one of them. Some asked me if things were safe, sort of joking. But even those who kept quiet, you knew they were thinking about the bombs. -- GAZETTA CULBRETH, a toll collector at the Lincoln Tunnel.  [ 22:5. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: He Shoots, He Scores! (In 2 Languages!)
nytimes_articles.abstract: French-Canadian hockey stars have sometimes struggled to coexist in the National Hockey League with their English-speaking teammates. The language and cultural barriers often extend to their relationships with the news media and the public.   Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, fluently bilingual and currently the best player in the game, is wary of discussing his hockey skills and the crises of his private life. Gentlemanly Pierre Turgeon, the blooming virtuoso of the Islanders, gets tongue-tied in two languages when talking about his talents: He labors even to come up with cliches.

nytimes_articles.headline: Junior R.O.T.C.? Who Needs It?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Is the Pentagon listening to President Clinton? Is our detail-oriented President paying total attention to his own budget?

In his State of the Union Address, he said America can "responsibly reduce our defense budget" in the post-cold-war world. Why then does he now support the Pentagon's effort to more than double the size of its Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps program for high school students?

nytimes_articles.abstract: Heady: Designer hats worn by Betty Maxwell, the widow of the late publishing tycoon Robert Maxwell, to meet Queen Elizabeth or attend the Royal Ascot races are to be auctioned July 13 in London by Christie's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Protest Resolution at U.N.
nytimes_articles.abstract: A group of Muslim and other countries in the Security Council is sponsoring a resolution aimed at lifting the arms embargo against Muslim-led Bosnian troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina and authorizing United Nations forces to use air strikes against Serbian artillery positions.   The resolution is given a poor chance of passage because of the opposition of the European countries, including Britain, France and Russia, all of whom have vetoes in the council.

nytimes_articles.headline: Space Policy Is Foreign Policy
nytimes_articles.abstract:
This week's narrow victory for the Space Station Freedom in the House carried some upsetting news for the project's supporters. The Congressmen showed no inclination to invite serious Russian cooperation on the station's design -- as recommended by the White House -- probably because they fear some domestic jobs would be lost. Unfortunately, NASA officials, thankful that the project is still alive, are unlikely to challenge Congressional reluctance.

There is no doubt Russian expertise could help the project. Russia has more experience in sustained manned space flight and large launch vehicles than any other country. A University of Maryland study commissioned by NASA found that a wider use of Russian technology could reduce costs by up to a billion dollars a year after the station was operational. Yet this savings potential was never mentioned in House debate.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Atlanta Braves Share With Boss Tweed; Prodigious Loser
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "A Noble Loser" (editorial, June 14), on the losing streak of the Mets pitcher Anthony Young, encouragingly notes that only a pitcher of some talent would be permitted to stick around long enough to set that kind of record. You might also have noted that the major league record for most losses in a pitching career (315) is held by the same pitcher who holds the record for most victories (511) -- Cy Young. JAMES J. HANKS JR. Baltimore, June 16, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Rights Forum Ends in Call For a Greater Role by U.N.
nytimes_articles.abstract: After dire predictions that it could mark a serious setback for the human rights movement, a World Conference on Human Rights ended on a surprisingly optimistic note tonight as delegates called on the United Nations to play a larger role in denouncing abuses.   Western delegations were particularly pleased that, after lengthy bargaining, the conference endorsed an American proposal for the creation of a new post of High Commissioner on Human Rights.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kennedy Quotes in New Book Are Invented
nytimes_articles.abstract: Joe McGinniss's forthcoming book about Senator Edward M. Kennedy, "The Last Brother," includes a riveting description of Mr. Kennedy and his sister Eunice Shriver standing at their father's bedside in November 1963, struggling to break the news that President John F. Kennedy had been shot.    The father had suffered a crippling stroke two years earlier, and the Senator hesitated. "He was going to speak," Mr. McGinniss writes. "He just needed one more moment to think of how to begin. And so he stood at the foot of the bed, as mute as his father, his hands clasped behind his back, unable even to look the old man in the eye.

nytimes_articles.headline: It's a Seventh-Inning Fold for Saberhagen and Mets
nytimes_articles.abstract: For a while, Bret Saberhagen had to hope for salvation. Winless in six weeks, ineffective against nonexpansion ball clubs, Saberhagen pitched through six innings last night at Shea Stadium with a lively fastball and a reassuring lead.   Then, in a matter of minutes, it all fell apart.

nytimes_articles.abstract: While question marks linger over some of the companies scheduled for privatization by the French government, it seems that Elf, the state-owned oil company, should do well. At least, it will if this week's note on the company from the international inves

nytimes_articles.headline: Wachtler and Silverman End Their Fiscal Tie, Lawyers Say
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lawyers for Sol Wachtler, the former Chief Judge of New York State, and Joy Silverman, his former lover, have reached a tentative settlement over the future of the Silverman family's $24 million trust fund, both sides said today.   Once the agreement, is signed by Surrogate Edward A. Baker of Nassau County, it will sever the last links between the judge and the socialite he barraged with obscene and threatening letters after she broke off an affair with him. On March 31, Mr. Wachtler pleaded guilty to threatening to kidnap Ms. Silverman's daughter. He is to be sentenced on Aug. 9.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Finds 'Cheerleading' In Monitoring of Empire
nytimes_articles.abstract: A United States Senate subcommittee examining Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield criticizes state insurance regulators, who missed even the most obvious signs of trouble, and expensive auditors, who made only the most cursory examinations of the company. But it says that at the heart of Empire's deep financial crisis is the "gross mismanagement" of the company's own top executives.   The 200-page report offers a devastating portrait of the company that insures 8.2 million people, mostly in New York. It charges that Empire is losing money because of service so abysmal that some of the biggest institutions in America -- from Fortune 500 companies to universities and labor unions -- have dropped their insurance policies and turning elsewhere, even if they have to pay more.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russia Cuts Gas Supply To Estonia in a Protest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Russia halted deliveries of natural gas to the Baltic state of Estonia today in a move seen as retribution for a new Estonian residency law condemned by Moscow as a form of ethnic "apartheid."   Although Russian officials said the gas cutoff was because of a backlog of unpaid debts, the Estonian Prime Minister, Mart Laar, called the move a grave act that could lead to the closing of local factories, according to the news agency Baltfax.

nytimes_articles.headline: Opening a Wound on Staten Island
nytimes_articles.abstract: Supporters of the Staten Island Homeport reacted with bitter resignation to yesterday's decision by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission to close the base.   The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, a longtime advocate for the Navy base, called the closing a wound to the borough's pride.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rookie Tips His Nervousness
nytimes_articles.abstract: After his first major league hit tonight, the kid made his first rookie mistake. Jeffrey Hammonds had just lifted Jim Abbott's pitch into left field for a run-scoring single in the sixth inning. The hit sliced Baltimore's deficit to 6-3 in a game they would eventually take from the Yankees, 7-6.   The 46,312 fans at Camden Yards rose and cheered Hammonds's achievement. Hammonds did not know what to do. He looked around. He stared at the ground. Finally, Davey Lopes, the first base coach, told him to tip his helmet. Hammonds did. The fans roared again and then they finally sat down.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corruption Scandal Involving Minister Threatens Rabin's Cabinet
nytimes_articles.abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who in nearly a year in office has endured more perils than Pauline, found his Government's stability called into question once again this week with the looming indictment of his Interior Minister on corruption charges.   Although there seems scant chance that the Rabin Government will fall, the fault lines that the corruption scandal creates in his coalition could hurt his ability to negotiate peace agreements with the Palestinians and neighboring Arab countries.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; A Tribute Gets to the Heart of Art Blakey
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The Incredible School of Blakey," a tribute to the drummer Art Blakey at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday in the JVC Jazz Festival, really started with the first tune of the second half. The concert's producer, Ira Gitler, had reassembled Blakey's last great band -- Wynton Marsalis on trumpet, Bobby Watson and Billy Pierce on saxophones, James Williams on piano, Dennis Irwin on bass -- and had Elvin Jones on drums. Mr. Jones went into a patented Blakey backbeat, the band went into the melody of Mr. Watson's "Wheel Within a Wheel," and everything that was so great about Blakey and his groups appeared.   The concert had a shaky start, opening with groups made up mostly of former Blakey band members who performed endless solos, reminding the audience how dull Blakey's shows could sometimes be. The saxophonist Jackie McLean rose above it all, tearing through a set of tunes with absolute precision. On his "Dig," he threw every note with intent, measuring his lines and improvising with a real flow. The trumpeter Donald Byrd, who has recently been heard to better effect singing "I Like to Party" with the rapper Guru, produced weak solos that slowly vanished.

nytimes_articles.headline: JUSTICES INCREASE WORKERS' BURDEN IN JOB-BIAS CASES
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ruling in an important civil rights case, a divided Supreme Court today made it substantially harder for employees to prove they suffered discrimination on the job.   Until now, a worker could often win a discrimination case by showing that the employer gave the court a dishonest explanation for a dismissal or other action that appeared discriminatory.

nytimes_articles.headline: Casinos' Newest Draw Is Old Favorite: Poker
nytimes_articles.abstract: Art Donovan, the Baltimore Colts All-Pro defensive tackle from the team's glory years, matched two down treys with two more on the flop and won the first hand of live poker in New Jersey casino history today.   Mr. Donovan hunched his beamy shoulders over a poker table at the Sands Hotel and Casino with some other invited sports stars -- and some nobodies from the press -- to open the state's newest game of chance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miami Names an Athletic Director
nytimes_articles.abstract: The University of Miami yesterday named its top lawyer as its new athletic director.   PAUL DEE, who had been serving as interim director of intercollegiate athletics for the second time, said one of his top priorities would be the continued development of the Big East Conference.

nytimes_articles.headline: F.B.I. Chief Is on the Road as Crises Flare
nytimes_articles.abstract: This morning at the Federal Bureau of Investigation's headquarters someone pinned a note on the bulletin board outside an employee changing room. Addressed to "W.S.S.," the initials of William S. Sessions, it said, "Time to clean out your locker."   The note reflected the exasperation of many bureau employees about Mr. Sessions, who is fighting almost alone to keep his job. Those internal critics say he is presiding as little more than a figurehead over an agency roiled with discord five months after a harsh internal ethics report on the Director's conduct made his ultimate departure seem inevitable.

nytimes_articles.headline: FOR SALE/SOLD
nytimes_articles.abstract: Blasts from the past: One of Dizzy Gillespie's trademark bent trumpets was sold for $50,600 at a Sotheby's auction of entertainment and Hollywood memorabilia. The Hard Rock Café bought one of Elvis Presley's jumpsuits for $17,250 and a pair of Jimi

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Pilobolus Demonstrates How Varied Is Its Variety
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pilobolus unveiled a lavish array of dances on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, rather like a street merchant setting out bright-colored wares. At their best, Pilobolus dances have a wonderfully rich simplicity. But there was something to enjoy even in the less impressive pieces on this second program of the company's four-week engagement.   The evening opened with "Untitled," a 1975 work created by Pilobolus's original performers -- Robby Barnett, Alison Chase, Martha Clarke, Moses Pendleton, Michael Tracy and Jonathan Wolken -- as many of the company's dances are. "Untitled" is the Pilobolus classic in which two women repeatedly rise to twice their height, then subside from that towering perspective. On an idyllic Edwardian picnic together, they encounter two dandies, have children, then settle back for a spell on dandy rocking chairs. One can watch the dance as magical shape-play and illusion or as social commentary. The fine cast caught every nuance.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Late Balanchine, Without a Letdown
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Ballet's selective survey of George Balanchine's works draws to a close tomorrow with a giant coda, a six-hour program of excerpts that includes guest artists. The home team, however, has been steadily and splendidly inching the Balanchine Celebration toward a chronological finish.   "Walpurgisnacht Ballet" (1980) and "Mozartiana" (1981) were seen for the first time in the festival on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. The last chronological entry, this afternoon, will be Balanchine's 1981 version of the Garland Dance from "The Sleeping Beauty."

nytimes_articles.headline: :Prescribing Expatriate Health Insurance
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF you are planning a temporary move overseas, you probably wouldn't dream of leaving the family home empty without some form of insurance protection. By the same token, health insurance should be high-up on your list of priorities. Yet, horror stories of

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: For most newlyweds, a honeymoon is an escape from reality before they settle down to the responsibilities of everyday life. For CROWN PRINCE NARUHITO, 33, heir to Japan's Chrysanthemum Throne, and CROWN PRINCESS MASAKO, 29, the Harvard and Oxford-educated former diplomat, it means purification rituals, offerings to goddesses, visits to burial grounds and separate bedrooms.    The couple arrived at the town of Ise by train yesterday to begin their first trip outside of Tokyo since their wedding on June 9, The Associated Press reported. Palace officials emphasized that the trip was strictly business.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : Fidelity Expanding to Meet Growing German Demand
nytimes_articles.abstract: Germany is where the action is, according to Fidelity, the international fund management firm. Fidelity has just announced an expansion of its operations in Luxembourg, the tax-privileged EC member state. ."Sales into our Luxembourg Fidelity Funds

nytimes_articles.headline: Diplomacy Can Disarm North Korea
nytimes_articles.abstract: North Korea hasn't built nuclear arms, but its ambitions are worrisome. Washington has been coaxing it to remain in the community of non-nuclear nations. Patient and persistent diplomacy has already borne fruit: the North recently said it would "suspend" its decision to renounce the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The next step is to gain access to all the North's nuclear sites. That will require more coaxing when talks between the two nations resume Monday.    The Nonproliferation Treaty and a 1991 agreement with South Korea oblige Pyongyang to allow routine and special inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency and to arrange mutual North-South inspections. The North-South agreement also prohibits Pyongyang from reprocessing spent nuclear fuel into bomb-making plutonium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Philharmonic Concerts, Outdoors and Free
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York Philharmonic will open its 29th season of free concerts in the parks on Monday with a program of works by Mozart ("Eine Kleine Nachtmusik"), Rossini ("William Tell" overture) and Mussorgsky ("Pictures at an Exhibition"). The concert, directed by the orchestra's assistant conductor, Sam Wong, will end with a fireworks display.   The program is to be repeated at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx on Tuesday; Great Kills Park, S.I., on July 6; Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on July 8; Cunningham Park, Jamaica, Queens, on July 9, and Heckscher State Park, East Islip, L.I., on July 10.

nytimes_articles.headline: Software Stock:There Are No Blue Chips
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE prodigious success of Microsoft Corp., the U.S. software company whose market capitalization earlier this year outstripped that of IBM Corp,. has prompted speculation among investors over the identity of the "next Microsoft." But picking win

nytimes_articles.headline: A Role for the Khmer Rouge
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Khmer Rouge rebels, who only weeks ago seemed poised to use violence to disrupt United Nations-sponsored peace efforts here, said today that they wanted an advisory role in Cambodia's newly elected Government.   In a remarkable change of heart given its earlier declaration that the elections last month were a "stinking theatrical farce," the Maoist-inspired guerrilla group said in a radio broadcast that it had accepted an offer from Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's head of state, to have members serve as advisers to the interim Government. Rebel Leader to See Prince    Officials of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cambodia said the titular leader of the Khmer Rouge, Khieu Samphan, would meet with Prince Sihanouk this summer in North Korea, where the Prince has a home, and that a lower-level Khmer Rouge representative would travel to Phnom Penh next week to discuss the rebels' new role.

nytimes_articles.headline: Beliefs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although Kathryn Bishop teaches at a Roman Catholic university, she used to attach little importance to its religious identity. A few weeks ago, the young assistant professor of special education at the University of San Diego changed her mind.    "Now I'm proud to be at a Catholic university," she said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Walking Blues: Habyan Can't Find Plate in 10th
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Orioles have been playing host to raucous house parties at Camden Yards. The rules are simple. The Orioles provide the music, the setting and the people. All the opposing teams have to do is stop by, play a little baseball, but make sure they leave as losers.   The Yankees almost broke the rules tonight. After eight innings, they led, 6-4, and it looked like the resilient bunch would invade the house party, topple the Orioles and send everyone home disgusted.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : The Real Investment Value:It Depends on the Currency
nytimes_articles.abstract: Beware the currency factor. It is an old lesson, but one that needs to be constantly re-learned: The success of an investment depends very much on the currency in which it is calculated. .Take the example of CMI, the international arm of Clerical Medic

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   SEATTLE MARINERS -- Activated Chris Bosio, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Optioned Jim Converse, pitcher, to Calgary of the Pacific Coast League.   National League   FLORIDA MARLINS -- Optioned Mitch Lyden, catcher, to Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League. Designated Junior Felix, outfielder, for assignment.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Attack on Jordan Timed for King's Visit
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   There was nothing new in "Report Describes Jordan's Aid to Iraq During War" (news article, June 17).

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigerian Who Voided Vote Offers Democracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nigeria's military leader, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, insisted today that a democratically elected government would be installed as scheduled in August, despite his annulment of presidential elections held this month.    General Babangida, speaking to reporters after a meeting of senior military and police officers in Nigeria's capital, Abuja, said he would explain his plans in a speech to the nation on Saturday. The speech was originally scheduled for tonight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Regents Keep TV Program Out of Public Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York State Board of Regents reaffirmed its ban against a nationwide satellite news program for schoolchildren in public classrooms today, asserting that the 2 minutes of commercials in the 12-minute program treat students as "commodities to be exploited."   The 14-to-1 vote means New York remains the only state to have successfully prohibited public schools from using the program, Channel One. Channel One is shown in about 100 private schools in New York State.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Atlanta Braves Share With Boss Tweed
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "A Noble Loser" (editorial, June 14) commiserated with the 21st consecutive loss by Anthony Young, the New York Mets pitcher, and explained: "He is closing steadily on the major league mark of 23, set in 1910-11 by Cliff Curtis of the old (and legendarily inept) Boston Braves."

nytimes_articles.headline: Panel Votes to Close Staten Island Base; Spares New London
nytimes_articles.abstract: Virtually ending any significant Navy presence in New York City, a Presidential commission voted today to close the Staten Island Homeport and move its ships and sailors to Virginia and Florida.    The decision by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission appears to put an end to one of the Navy's most modern installations, which until 1991 had been the focus of a debate over allowing nuclear-armed ships to be based in New York Harbor.  The panel rejected, however, a Pentagon recommendation to shrink the submarine base at New London, Conn.  Other Major Closings    In a body blow to California and South Carolina, the seven-member commission also voted to close the Navy base and shipyard in Charleston, S.C., and a large shipyard and two Navy bases in the San Francisco Bay area. Combined, they employ more than 14,000 civilians, and community officials estimate the closings could indirectly cause the loss of two to three times that many jobs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Afghan War's Web Encircles A Militant Islamic Movement
nytimes_articles.abstract: A widening skein of relationships and travels, from Afghan war fervor to New York tenement life, is emerging as investigators track the disparate lives of the suspects arrested in the latest plot to bomb and terrorize New York City.   On East Eighth Street in lower Manhattan, neighbors yesterday remembered one of the suspects, Tarig El-Hassan, as a resident of an apartment building busy with households of Muslim militants who repeatedly journeyed back and forth to that distant combat viewed by Islamic fundamentalists as a holy war. Some bragged of their exploits as bomb makers in the war and as supporters of the militant Islamic movement in America, frightened neighbors related.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yichang Journal; Now Russians Wait on the Chinese
nytimes_articles.abstract: To promote international cultural exchanges, the restaurant manager explained with a straight face, she allows Chinese customers to hug the restaurant's Russian hostesses.   "They can hug, because that is a foreign custom," said Meng Qingmin, one of a wave of Chinese restaurateurs who hire young Russian women to chat with and snuggle up to male diners. "It's a foreign habit, and we want the girls to be at ease and feel able to follow their foreign customs."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz; Jarrett Brings Out His Romantic Streak And Runs With It
nytimes_articles.abstract: Midway in the second half of his "Standards" concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, the pianist Keith Jarrett delivered a breathtaking performance of "I Thought About You" that embodied everything people love most about his music.   For all of his explorations into the classical repertory and his excursions into minimalism and meditational music, the side of Mr. Jarrett that is most appreciated is the part that is a disciple of Bill Evans. As Evans did, Mr. Jarrett has an intensely romantic streak and the improvisational skill to extrude a pop melody into cascading runs whose quicksilver chromatic harmonies change almost faster than the ear can follow.

nytimes_articles.headline: President Finally Speaks To Man Claiming Kinship
nytimes_articles.abstract: After almost a week of getting their wires crossed, President Clinton finally spoke by telephone today with the California man who says he is Mr. Clinton's half-brother.   But getting a White House account of the exchange was something like pulling teeth. The press office issued only a terse three-sentence statement reporting that a 15-minute conversation had taken place. It said the two men agreed to meet "at some point in the future."

nytimes_articles.headline: Capriati and Agassi Getting the Bounces
nytimes_articles.abstract: That green shadow-striping of Wimbledon's grass courts, the sign of a healthy lawn and the low-slung bounce favored by the dying breed of serve-and-volley players that flourishes here, has begun to give way to the scars of use after a rainless week. The lawns are parched, the bounces are higher, the bomb alerts have begun and topspin artisans like Jennifer Capriati and Andre Agassi are finding it easier to dominate, manipulate and dictate from the baseline.   Comfortable at last, the seventh-seeded Capriati, an ardent Wimbledon champion wannabe, chopped away this afternoon at the giantess who owns the most powerful serve and strokes in the women's game, Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands. Capriati's makeshift grass-court machinations on Center Court undid the traditional serve-and-volley tactics of Schultz in a 7-5, 4-6, 6-2 victory.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Yorker to Head Chicago Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Chicago Board of Education selected Argie K. Johnson, the deputy chancellor for instruction in New York City, today as general superintendent of the Chicago school system, a deficit-ridden district struggling with decentralization.   Mrs. Johnson, 54 years old, had been a candidate to replace the departing New York Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez. She said she had chosen Chicago in a last-minute flurry of telephone calls and pitches from both sides because of the potential she sees in Chicago's decentralization program, an effort to give parents more control over schools. Under decentralization, which began in 1989, the district has set up parent-dominated governing boards for each of Chicago's 551 schools.

nytimes_articles.headline: Women's Coach Signs Major Contract
nytimes_articles.abstract: PAT SUMMITT was beginning to wonder what she needed to get a contract as women's basketball coach at the University of Tennessee. Now she knows: patience, three national titles and 499 career victories.

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Tell Subcommittee Insurer Altered Data In Order to Mislead
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two former employees of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield appeared before a United States Senate subcommittee today and gave the first public evidence that the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer intentionally misled the New York State Legislature and Insurance Department for years.   The witnesses said they were told by Empire's chief financial officer that loss figures sent to the state had been "manipulated" to make them "politically correct." They said they were transferred from the company's executive suite after discovering that Empire kept two sets of books. And one said that Empire officials joked about the two sets of numbers at a party.

nytimes_articles.headline: Budget Vote Drives Lautenberg to Unfamiliar Side
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton twisted his arm for more than an hour. Vice President Al Gore weighed in. And well into the early morning hours, senior Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee urged him to think of the party's best interests.   But "when all was said and done," Senator Frank R. Lautenberg said, "I could not bring myself to vote for a package that was so detrimental to New Jersey's interests." So Mr. Lautenberg, the junior Democratic Senator from New Jersey, joined some of his party's most conservative senators today to vote against the Democrats' budget package.

nytimes_articles.headline: Words Aren't Violence
nytimes_articles.abstract: First incident: I am walking on K Street in Washington when a black man (I am white) soliciting for an AIDS charity approaches me. When I shake my head and hurry past, he yells: "What does that mean, shaking your head? What does that mean? You're a  [ expletive deleted ]  educated redneck!"   Question: Has this man, with his apparently racist slur, violated my human rights?

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : U.S. Government Bonds Provide Negative Returns
nytimes_articles.abstract: The sustained bull run in U.S. bonds had already petered out, but last month was still exceptional in providing a negative return for investors in U.S. government bonds. The fall of 0.41 percent, as calculated by Kemper Investment Management, the London-

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON NOMINEE DEFENDS HIMSELF
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's choice to head the National Endowment for the Humanities, who has been attacked by conservatives as an apostle of "political correctness," told a Senate committee today that he now believed that campus codes to restrict offensive speech were a mistake.    The nominee, Sheldon Hackney, president of the University of Pennsylvania, denounced political correctness, saying that "it would be a serious problem if it were to capture a campus."

nytimes_articles.headline: Portrait of a Serial Bomber Emerges After Parcel Blasts
nytimes_articles.abstract: Federal investigators who have spent years trying to crack the case of a serial bomber who they say struck again twice this week think he is an obsessive-compulsive white man who was reared in the Chicago area and probably has had menial jobs.   They believe he is a neat dresser who leads a meticulously organized life, the kind of person who likes to make lists. He is likely to be quiet and would be an almost ideal neighbor. He has had at least a high school education, and possibly more. His self-esteem is low -- and most likely he has had problems dealing with women -- because of his physical flaws, either real or perceived.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Nation's Growing Role as Staging Ground for Islamic Extremists
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sudanese passports held by eight Muslim fundamentalists charged with planning terrorist acts in New York cast a spotlight on the growing role of the African country as a staging ground for radical Islamic extremists.   Since coming to power in a 1989 coup, the military government of General Omar al-Bashir and its partner in government, the Islamic National Front led by Sheik Hassan al-Turabi, have instituted one of the strictest Muslim fundamentalist social orders in the world. Exporting Revolution    Two years ago Sudan struck a strategic alliance with Iran. Western and Egyptian security experts say Iran supplies the Sudan with free oil, sells some arms and trains Sudanese and Arab fundamentalists to form vanguard Muslim militias.

nytimes_articles.headline: Holyfield Camp Is Looking Ahead
nytimes_articles.abstract: Litigants and lawyers, heavyweights and lightweights, perennial enemies and friends by necessity gathered today. That can only mean a big fight looms.   Depending on whose attorney one speaks to, Saturday night's Evander Holyfield-Alex Stewart 12-rounder is a heavyweight championship elimination, or just another example of a boxing monopoly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three Concerts of Bach Organ Music Are Planned
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three concerts of organ music by J. S. Bach are planned on Wednesdays at St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street, Manhattan. The series, "Bach on the von Beckerath Organ," starts on Wednesday with a recital by Robert Barrows, the music director at the church. The program is to include two Toccatas and Fugues in D minor, two Preludes and Fugues in C and selected Chorale Preludes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Space Policy Is Foreign Policy
nytimes_articles.abstract:
This week's narrow victory for the Space Station Freedom in the House carried some upsetting news for the project's supporters. The Congressmen showed no inclination to invite serious Russian cooperation on the station's design -- as recommended by the White House -- probably because they fear some domestic jobs would be lost. Unfortunately, NASA officials, thankful that the project is still alive, are unlikely to challenge Congressional reluctance.

There is no doubt Russian expertise could help the project. Russia has more experience in sustained manned space flight and large launch vehicles than any other country. A University of Maryland study commissioned by NASA found that a wider use of Russian technology could reduce costs by up to a billion dollars a year after the station was operational. Yet this savings potential was never mentioned in House debate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yen's Rise Can Resist A Government's Fall
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE yen ended a volatile week of trading pretty much where it began, despite the fall of the government, and has recouped most of a sharp decline that began two weeks ago. Nevertheless, the drop was its biggest in months and suggests to some that the trem

nytimes_articles.headline: So Look Who's a Goalie For the Rangers: Healy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two former Islander goalies were the featured attractions today at the National Hockey League congress. The one who is still active, Glenn Healy, ended up with the Rangers after a series of drafts and a trade. The one who is retired, Billy Smith, was elected to the Hall of Fame.   Healy, an Islander star this past spring as the team unexpectedly reached the third round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, was chosen by the new Anaheim Mighty Ducks on Thursday in the first phase of the expansion draft. In the secondary phase this afternoon, he was selected by the Tampa Bay Lightning. But Tampa quickly traded Healy to the Rangers for a third-round pick in Saturday's entry draft of amateurs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Panel Is Divided on Waiver For Sale of Post to Murdoch
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch's bid to buy The New York Post hung in the balance today, as the battle lines hardened at the Federal Communications Commission between supporters and opponents of his request for a waiver he needs to complete the deal.   The acting chairman of the commission, James H. Quello, came out strongly in support of Mr. Murdoch but said the other two voting commissioners were nowhere near agreement on the issue.

nytimes_articles.headline: BRIEFCASE : Companies Put More Stress On Security of Expatriates
nytimes_articles.abstract: How safe is the expatriate employee? Although incidents of terrorism and kidnappings were down last year, international companies are paying more attention to the security of their employees. .That is one conclusion reached by Runzheimer International,

nytimes_articles.headline: Suns Bid Farewell to Chambers
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Phoenix Suns will not exercise their option on TOM CHAMBERS, ending the four-time All-Star's career with the team.   Suns Owner JERRY COLANGELO announced the decision yesterday after speaking with Chambers by telephone the night before. Chambers left Wednesday for a vacation in Hawaii.
